reviewText: I was on top of the world. I had it all. Fame, money, women, and league title wins. Then, the new season came around and we were ready to do it all over again. We went on to lose our first match, but I figured it must surely be bad luck. Then, the second game came around, and we lost that one too. Interesting. Third time's a charm, right? Wrong. It was obvious to everyone that it was a fluke, though. Fourth time? Referee's fault. Fifth? THEY LITERALLY CHEATED.\n\nAt the end of the season, the team found themselves in the relegation zone. As I stood looking at my reflection in the mirror, I said to myself, Don't worry

reviewText:
This review is intended for the experienced FM player. If you are new to the series, or indeed the genre, you should buy this game. It is by far the best available in the genre. Highly recommended.

However, if you have owned virtually every CM/FM game that has ever been released, then perhaps the following comments will constitute a review which is closer to your heart?

Somewhere along the line, these games lost their soul. The most identifiable yardstick along this path was the moment the developers introduced overall star ratings for players. There was a time, in early CM games, when signing a player was a risk. You would look at their form, stats and overall value and make a decision. Sometimes, you would buy a flop and othertimes you would make a great signing. Now all you need to do is have a good scout and you can go on the star rating they provide. That might be good for your average ADHD fifa manager type players, but people buying these games, for the most part, WANT to spend time trying to make these decisions and don't want to have their hands held through the process. In a real-world scenario, a player who has scored 20+ goals in a season immediately attracts interest from bigger clubs. In this game however, you will simply overlook such a player if their star rating is poor. In these games form has absolutely no relevance when making signings. This is NOT an accurate simulation of how decisions are made in real life.

If you are a long-standing player of these games, ask yourself this question - when was the last time you bought a player who ended up not being good enough to make it at your club? This is something real-world managers live and die by, but is an element of football management which has been woefully overlooked by the developers. Somewhere along the way the developers have made the hardest decision in football management the easiest one. Signing new players should always be a risk. Think of the countless examples in real life of signings which on paper should have been stars. If there is one thing which is clearly evident, it is that even the most experienced and talented of managers occasionally buy players who flop. This should be the most important aspect of any football management simulation. Instead, this game provides you with god-like ability to predict just how good a player will be in the future through an overall star rating. In real-life, managers would make such predictions through a combination of the player's professionalism, age, determination, injury history and availabilility of experienced players for the youngster to learn from. These factors would also fluctuate over time and be subject to change. Hence, a player like Michael Johnson at Man City comes an goes.  By forcing players to consider these things the developers could make this game SO much more rewarding and return the franchise partway to its former roots.

As for the matchday engine, it is simply a non-event. The quality is just not there to warrant ever using this view. The ardent FM fan will not even care about the 3D view as it is not the aspect of the game which they find rewarding. Rather, it is taking the plunge and signing players and working them into a functional tactical system. Incidentally, tactics is the one area of the game which the developers have virtually got spot on. You cannot sail through a season just repeat using the same system like in the good old days.

My suggestion, stop trying make a stats-driven simulation and try to return some atmosphere to the game. You can make a start by providing authentic match day sounds. I could go for hours explaining how this game could be improved, but ultimately this is intended as a review and not a 'blue-sky' suggestion session for the developers.

I will obviously keep buying these games, if only for the reason that there is no other franchise which comes close in this genre. But everytime I buy the latest version a little piece of me (and the genre) dies. It is for this reason that I have to send a message to the world that as long as this game is not fulfilling its enormous potential, I cannot in good conscience recommend it.

reviewText:
Football Manager 2016 Beta First Impressions
Hey guys, I'm about to write my first impressions about the game, but keep in mind that this is beta / pre-order version. Also, this review is intended for Football Manager players that already know how to play this game.

Pros:


Most advanced animations yet in any Football Manager edition. What I mean by that is the fact that FINALLY you can see the difference in Flair / Quality between 2 players. New dribblings, crosses, decisions and finishing in front of goal. It was FM13 since I've been asking for more realistic dribblings / decisions / crosses in the final third but the game never got quite there, until now. Let me give you a short example: I am playing as AC Milan and Jeremy Menez was attacking the right flank as a Winger-Attack. In any of the previous versions, he would have done 3 possible things: attack the byline and cross, cutting into the penalty area or pass the ball back to the overlappting full back. Now, I noticed something absolutly beautiful: He did neither of those. His decision was to dribble 2 players like they were nothing by cutting inside the penalty area and then he launched a lobbed-cross to Luiz Adriano who was rushing forward from a deeper position. Now, besides his way of dribbling (which i've never seen before in FM), we can easily notice another MAGNIFICENT improvement: lobbed crosses. This kind of crosses are a must in a game like FM and I am finally happy it was introduced. So yes, new animations / decisions / dribblings / crossings. You can finally see the difference between 15 Flair and 18 Flair so to speak.
Game is in a much better state beta wise than it was last year (loading times, match engine and leagues)
Fast loading / saving times. Last year's beta was awful regarding saving times. It was something that eventually got fixed, but FM16 doesn't have this problem at all. In fact, to me it seems than the game loads/saves faster than FM15.
3D Match Engine is another thing that pleasantly surprised me (played 3 games). By this I mean it feels smoother, no visible glitches and artefacts. Last year we had all sorts of problems with 3d engine performance until it got fixed (the game ran choppy and stuttering a lot on anything above medium" quality no matter how powerful your machine was). In this regard
date: FM 2016 shines right from the start. I am able to play the game on highest graphical settings.\nOne of the biggest improvements in my opinion is ProZone analysis tool. This tool is so so much better than what we had before. If you are the kind of manager that likes to keep tabs on every aspect of the tactic you are creating

reviewText:
If you've never had a Football Manager game before? It's worth getting. If you have FM15? It's not worth the upgrade.

Firstly, I've gotten promoted twice in a row and qualified for champions league in years 3 - I'm going OK! I have played it for years and years, this review is not on the back of me doing badly in the game.

Basics*
*(note - a lot about match engine, but this is a large part of what makes the game enjoyable for me)

The main issue I encountered was the quality of the match engine. Prior to the release, we heard about how the developers were improving this area of the game. However;
-Goalkeepers are making STUPID decisions, the visual standard you watch would have been disappointing in a game that's 10 years old. It hasn't a patch on the FIFA Manager game I played 10 years ago.
-Defenders are nearly as bad - they can't track a run, they give away stupid penaltys and can never cover the back post
-Tactics enforced can't really be seen in play. If you target a side in your tactics, the stat's never display this, the highlights never show it.
-Match engine overall has not improved. The lack of progress since FM15 is absolutely TERRIBLE
-Negotations are still unrealistic - small clubs will still demand 30 million for a hot prospect who has never played a game for a club.
-It still hasn't allowed for better negotiations on contracts etc. - I would have liked more career development talks etc. when taking on and dealing with young players.
-The press conferences are just irritating - again, very little progression from last year. Even most of the questions are the same.
-The 'new club' feature just isn't good. Picking a new team has been made far too irritating and long winded by the way you have to search. It's as if the developers got bored at this part and just gave up before they were finished. I was really excited about this feature, but it has a number of HUGE flaws too such as you're able to get players who haven't got work permits, then if they can't be renewed at the end of the season - they're gone (I lost half of my team after the first season on free transfers because of it).

Overall, I would advise getting FM15 for a fraction of the price and getting an update for the new players etc. This is one of the worst updates I've played and it's really not worth the effort that has been put in since the release of FM15. I really don't think they're keeping with the times, there are lots of new features that they could of added but haven't.

reviewText:
A longtime player and huge fan of the FM series, yet every year there seems to be one or more elements which can make the gameplay infuriating and unbearable. Before I list my complaints, I would like to emphasize that I have no problems with winning games, competions or creating working tactics and that these complaints are merely observations which cause a huge amount of frustration.

- Goalkeeper intelligence is laughable as they will frequently concede goals easily in their close corner due to terrible placement and movement. And even with frequent clean sheets, your goalkeepers (or anyone else) rating will rarely reach an average above 7.0.

-Defenders (particularly centrebacks) will track a player's run only to make 180 turn and run away from the attacker, which usually results in an easy conceded goal. And it doesn't matter whether you play as Bayern or Gateshead, because you will concede more than a fair share of goals from crosses at the far post, due the defender(s) inability/will to follow the run made by the attacking player.

- You will never/rarely actually get a goal, when you need one. Whether it's drawing level or winning a close encounter. And to pile on the misery, the opposition will also more than often score in the dying minutes, snatching either a draw or win.

- The aforementioned point makes the matches feel extremely predictable as you either absolutely smash opposition, go ninety minutes without a single chance or get the dreaded late conceded goal and all is visible/predictable due to the way your/opposing players move about on the pitch during the whole match/last minutes.

- Different tactical approach isn't as visible on-screen as one might imagine, which gives little incentive to create/tweak own tactics.

- Corner instructions are ignored (short corner instruction results in floating crosses being hit).

- Generally lack of new features with the exception of the terrible manager creator screen.

reviewText:
Ah. Football Manager 2016. From the superb to the shocking.

Firstly, I must say if you're looking for a game with superb aesthetics, then Football Manager 2016 is the game for you. The menus, tactics, training, transfers, fixtures etc. screens look superb, as they always have and probably always will. Aesthetically it's a 10/10 game.

However, once you press that play button to start the match, it all turns truly dire. Never mind your coaching badges, your club's level or your standard of players/staff, you'll suffer (and receive - it can go both ways) some of the most shocking, and in some cases bizarre, pieces of gameplay you'll ever likely to see. Goalkeepers diving away from the ball, sometimes not diving at all, players not tracking the most blatant of runs, your star attacker continuously missing sitters while the computer's youth debutant with a finishing attribute of two bangs in a brace from outside the box. Those are just some of the things you can expect to see in Football Manager 2016 (though, that's been the case for years in FM to be honest.)

Admittedly, I'm definitely not the most skilled player, no question, but even so it's clear to see the game needs a lot of work to firstly get to the standard the developers give it and secondly to merit its price tag. I'd honestly say don't buy this game, I regret doing so especially given it's the same stuff (gameplay-wise) as in FM2015. I've been underwhelmed with FM for years now, they've seem to have slipped since the superb days of FM2009, FM2010 and FM2011.

But hey, this is just my opinion. Make a decision for yourself. It's OK to play, but it's definitely not enjoyable in my opinion. Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
(Disclaimer: I think I've burned out on FM.)

I'm tired of FM, because although the game is 'easy' - and it is, don't get me wrong, you can pick a team and either bludgeon your way through to titles, or you can be a savvy type of player and tactically mastermind your way to titles. Me? I'm one of those that bludgeons the game and the reason for that is simple;

There's a comprehensive lack of useful in-game documentation to help create sensible tactics. In fact, if you go on their official forums you'll find thorough posts (a bible's worth of pages) on how to defend, attack, counter attack and whatnot. It shouldn't be the case, that if I want to better understand the basics of the tactics creator, that I have to go out of the game to get access to that information.

Worse still, is when that information almost directly or indirectly contradicts in the in-game information. For example, Counter Attacking mentalities is stated in game to be a mentality to choose when you will lose the battle for possession

reviewText: Way too buggy, very few improvements over 15 (as usual). I used to be one of those FM addicts you read about and laugh/marvel at, my playing hours of FMs have dropped from  around 1700 hours per year in 11, 12, 13 and 14 to less than 1k for 15 and now I've barely even opened this one. Build a club is just the editor. The only good new thing is the online draft thing. Which is so slow you'll love the concept and then get incredibly mad it wasn't polished.\n\nNot recommended because of the bugs and incessant errors. It's been the same bloody game for 20 bloody years, you REALLY shouldn't be getting errors every day.

reviewText:
This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awful! How the hell do you ♥♥♥♥ up Football Manager 2016??

The whole game feels like it was cobbled together in a mad rush. Did the developers not give the creator's enough time to work on the ♥♥♥♥ing match engine?? The game is broken. Nothing works the way it should do.

The AI is ♥♥♥♥ing horrendous, you could have 20+ shots every game and score one goal, if that. The opposition has a ridiculous tendacity to dominate you, regardless of the gulf of class between the two sides. Your best player - you know the one with four to five ♥♥♥♥ing stars - will be humiliated and abused by the ♥♥♥♥♥est players imagineable. No matter how many times you change your tactics, i.e. retain possession, narrow attack etc, the AI is simply incapable of processing these very simple ♥♥♥♥ing instructions. When I tell my team to retain possession, to play at a low tempo... they do the exact ♥♥♥♥ing opposite. Coutinho, when of the best passers of the ball, will clear the ball away into touch despite having acres of space, with two players either side of him to distract the lone single ♥♥♥♥ing defender in their way. And what happens.... Coutinho clears the ball into ♥♥♥♥ing touch. Are you ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me SI??

Word of advice to every football fan... Do Not Buy This Game. Do Not. Do not support the continued production of recycled crap, this game is competely broken. If you really want to buy a FM buy last years FM 2015, but make sure you buy it during a sale. Or find other ways of acquiring it. SI are taking liberties now, they will continue to produce this broken trash if we keep buying it. Do not support this franchise... It is a complete waste of your time, effort and money. A walking, breathing, abortion which should have been left to die before its inception.

DO NOT BUY FOOTBALL MANAGER 2016!

reviewText: I have been playing FM since the time it was Championship Manager. FM12 for me was the last decent version of the game. Since FM13, the game lost the magic and became predictable and boring. Despite the disappointing FM13, 14 and 15, i decided to give the game one last chance. FM16 unfortunately, is no different than 13, 14 and 15. SI once again, failed to deliver a decent game. Match Engine is once again full of bugs. For example, the opposition scores a goal after one single shot very often and usually on the first minutes (under 10') of the game under. Opponent's most goals come from crosses.Also, if the opponent always scores the same number of goals with the half chances of my team. For example, if i score a goal with 4 shots, the opponent will score a goal with 2 shots. Check it out and you will understand what i mean, Tactics actually have no real effect. In general the main problem with FM is that what rarely happens in real football, happens very often on this game. The game is more like a Hockey Manager. In a few words, FM16 is a polished version of the disappointing FM15. Except the transfer update, the rest of the features are pointless. No way to buy FM again. I would suggest to people NOT to buy FM16. Waste of time and money.

reviewText:
I am an addict, like many football fans the FM franchise is a drug, we all get the latest fix every year.
However with each year that comes the cost of the drug is going up, the supplier is getting greedier.
Each year sees a few new graphics tweaks or menu changes which are largely cosmetic.
As other reviewers have noted, support is a joke. Thee are a number of glitches in the game not big, but signs of sloppy or hurried programming, as you play the game more, you notice a few things like this.
I had an issue with the game starting up on FM2015, wasn't satisfactorily sorted it, it may have been eventually, but I had lost interest by then.
After the latest update I am getting Game won't save messages" I've discovered that if I create a new Folder I can then save it
date: and can carry on for a day or so before it recurs. My HD is going to be littered with FM2016\ngame folders at the rate It's going.\nSo in summary FM2016 is really no better than previous versions
hoursPlayed: support is as bad as ever.\nBUT I am a sad addict and it satisfies my need.\nI have the same arguement with myself every year

reviewText:
Wow, what a difference!  FM16 is much better than the poor shadow of a game that FM15 was.

Just some quick comments:

1.  The goalie AI is miles better.  The reactions are more realistic, and diving saves are made when they are meant to.  A lot less opposition goals scored with keeper just standing there.  I feel like my team has a locked door again!!

2.  The defence AI is also much improved.  Where last year they would let players through easily, there is a real feeling that the defenders respond to tactics you set and that makes such a positive difference.

3.  I love the new animations for scoring, celebrating, remonstrating, falling and tackling.  I really like the little flicks of the ball that have been introduced as well.  Also some nice improvements in the build of players' faces on the pitch.  My computer was rated 3* for graphics, but there has been no problem with the best quality setting being used.

4.  The new tactics screen is super.  It makes it a lot more clear to use the 'pie' graphic to show whether the players are suited to a position and now a role.  Much much better.

5.  The new manager builder is a great idea.  I kind of managed to match my face but I have heavy stubble and glasses - any chance that SI could introduce facial hair and glasses settings for this?  Wouldn't mind so much if it was just for the match engine, but my attempt at my face comes up whenever I am quoted on screen and whatever.  However, that is the only thing I don't like about the manager builder.

6.  Injury frequency is much fairer than in FM15.  I no longer have an injury list the size of Glasgow.  I've gone from a consistent injury list of 8 first team players out to just 1 or 2 - much more realistic.  This makes such a difference SI - please don't change it when you release the final version.

7.  Injury type and associated time out of the team is much better balanced than in FM15.  The option to play through injury is good too.  SI have listened to us here, which is excellent.  I was kind of dreading playing this game after forking out for the beta, simply because the injury system crippled FM15 in my eyes, and I was afraid that this would be more of the same.  I am very happy that I have been proved wrong.

8.  The prozone tactical system is great.  Now we can access substitutions in a much slicker fashion, and it doesn't take an age to go through.  This helps the game continue quickly.

9.  There is a definite distinction between match fitness and match sharpness, and both affect the performance of the players in their own way.  A lot of thought has gone into this, and it works extremely well, even in beta.

Can you tell I'm a little impressed??

10.  I haven't tried the team builder yet but looking it over, it seems a great option.  I'll comment more fully when I have the chance.

SI, thank you for giving us a much better offering (so far) this season.  I will be playing this version of FM a lot more than I played the last one.

reviewText:
I love the FM series and have played each one for the last five years.

I'm enjoying it but have some mixed feelings. There are new details, the opta stats are fun - players are a little harder to keep happy, tactics feel a bit sharper, but there is nothing here that feels like a big step. It's just an evolution. You could update FM15 with FM16 rosters and what have you and not really notice a significant difference...and that's a shame. Even all the new animations are not really that obvious. I'm waiting for something to blow me away but year in year out, its just minor progress. I still played the hell out of their games so they are obviously doing something very right. But for the full price - I expect more bang for my buck as a year in year out customer.

But yes, I still recommend this game, absolutely.

reviewText:
This is the first time I have ever written a negative review and it pains me, however, as it stands now, I simply cannot recommend FM 2016 and regret that I purchased it.

I have been playing the series since CM 1998 and never once have I regretted purchasing the games until now.

Why the negative review?  Because in my opinion the Match Engine is simply broken.  Defending just doesn't work and is commical.  In 5 matches my keeper (Prem division) conceded 3 goals that slipped through his fingers and two goals from defender back passes.

I have spent the last 8 hours trying different tactics and formations and it seems very little actually affects gameplay.  Players do not follow instruction, defenders do not defend and goalies seem to make mistakes every game.

In addition, players do not follow instruction and seems regardless of what tactic/formation results do not alter (as mentioned, have been testing).

I have read they are looking to release a patch to fix some of the issues.  I will revisit this review at a later date and amend it if the patches actually fix the issues, but right now, I cannot recommend this game and would suggest sticking with 2015 instead until this has been patched to a playable state.

*sadface at posting negative review*

reviewText:
This review is based on being a FM/CM player for over 20 years and someone who only ever plays the full mode, not classic or touch.

If you have never played FM before then it is the best game you can play, it is the latest, most up to date FM and (excluding presentation) the best because while it doesnt add much, it is a subtle improvement on 15, just as 15 was on 14. Although if you can buy FM14 for under £5, then buy that, get an updated database and in terms of value to what you play there wont be to much difference.

The thumbs down is purely for players who play FM year in year out. This is just not worth the £35. I wouldnt have bought FM2016 but it was bought for me as a present that I didnt ask for.

If you are in any doubt then have a look at the new features on the store page, 3rd down is manager on the touchline. 3rd down, it must be pretty important, it must be a huge new feature! now scroll through the screenshots until you get to the picture of the manager. That is what you get. Basically a huge slap in the face to every long-term FM user.

On the Sports Interactive FM forums there is a huge wishlist thread with over 6000 replies. Pick any random page and there are countless wishes for in-depth training, media pressure, player interaction, ME improvments, Board improvements. With the exception of the ME there has been no noticeable improvement in any of these over the last two years. This year we are treated to new features such as create a club, fantasy draft and manager on the touchline. Fine new features in themselves, widely asked for? no.

The game is all to easy to create all conquering teams that win trophies year after year. In real life how many managers stay at the same club and keep constantly winning trophies? Obviously Sir Alex Ferguson and a few others, but it should be hard, really hard to do. Its just to easy in FM. How many young players who are deemed wonderkids in real life go on to actually become superstars? Not that many, a handful from each generation. Not so in FM, buy a wonderkid, play wonderkid, watch wonderkid fulfill potential. On the other hand, want to pluck a kid from the french second division who no one really rates and watch him suprise everyone (ala Marhez of Leicester), no chance. The constrictive CA/PA system wont allow that until a FM researcher updates it for you. Its a system that is showing its age. They may have served the series well, but many of the systems FM16 incorporates are basic and easy to control because they havent moved forward in the last few years.

Football Manager really hasnt moved forward with the times. 15 to 20 years ago a lot of managers did run the club from top to bottom but these days top, top clubs arent run like that. FM does a really poor job of reflecting this, sure there is the token Director of football, the token head of development, but again very simplistic, basic systems that just doesnt reflect top level football in 2016. Managing a top club in FM16 feels more like a quaint throwback to the 90s than an actual reflection of what fooball has become in the last 15 years.

3 years ago I thought FM was about where it should be. Now its coming across stale and out of ideas. Going by the wishlist thread in their own forums theres 100s of great ideas, but for whatever reason SI has entered the change UI, tag on some light weight features and sell for full price approach. Its sad to see. I will still play it, but every year its getting harder to justify paying £35 for a game that isnt moving forward and is no longer reflecting the sport I watch and read about. I will still rack up the hours, but more because there is no other game to buy than what SI have developed.

The FM series needs a huge shake up. Every year real life football grows, the juggernaught keeps getting bigger and expanding. Every year that goes by where we have new features like create a club and fantasy draft is another year where FM loses ground on the sport its trying to represent. Its sad that the people in control of the games direction have completely lost sight of what gave the game its cult following. It got the basics of the football world right and let the players imagination fill in the gaps and build from there. The basics of the FM world dont feel right anymore. Without that basic foundation the imagination has no support, FM needs imagination to work or it is just a game and FM was never just a game.

reviewText:
Alright, in hope that I can beat the unfunny reviews of this game, let’s crack this one out!

Football Manager 2016 is part of the continual football (or soccer depending on where you hail from) series. This is the eleventh game in the series and will release officially in November 2015. The game was made available early for people who pre-purchased the game to take part in the beta testing phase. This review is based off my time in the beta thus far.

The game play of FM16 is exactly the same as all of the others; you take management over a football team and run everything to do with the sporting side of it. This includes picking your team’s tactics, choosing which players to take part in matches, setting training regimes for your players, buying and selling players, agreeing contracts of your back room staff and players. Pretty much anything which a manager of a football team has to do, you also do in this game.  Each yearly release of FM comes with over 200+ changes compared to the last years. Some of this year’s biggest changes are as follows:

Players can now customize their player’s appearance. I have to admit, I wasn't a huge fan of this; mainly because I have no real interest in what my manager looks like in game, you hardly see the character at all. When creating my manager, it seems as if the actual appearance of your character doesn't change all that much when editing the face, you just get a strange looking mess of a face. For me, I hated this feature as it adds nothing real to the game.

The feature I am most excited about is the addition of a Fantasy draft - we see all sorts of drafts in American football, but not so in soccer. This feature will allow you to play with friends, set a budget, and draft your own team to go head to head with people online. I have played a bit of it so far, and it is awesome. It has a sort of pick up and play feel to it; if you have maybe just an hour to spare, rather than getting engrossed in the full game, load up a draft and play a couple of games. This is a welcome addition to the game if you ask me.

A create your own club feature has been added; this feature was already kind of included in previous generations of the game via the game's editor tool, but now it has been encorporated into the main game. Personally I have never used the old create a club feature, and probably won't even in this release. But what this does do is allow you to create a club from scratch and build it from the very bottom of the league structure and turn it into one of the best teams in the world. This is what I would call a hard mode difficulty setting and is a project which you need to set probably hundreds of hours to if you wants to succeed.

The main screen display you'll be seeing the majority of the time, looks just like an email inbox, you'll be sent items of news regarding your team, the league you are in, potential players you'd be interested in, injuries etc. You can choose whether to show more items, or fewer items depending on how in depth you want to go. When playing the matches, you'll be shown a 3D match engine. This has gotten a pretty heft face lift compared to previous titles, and it now looks even better than before. The players have a much smoother animation cycle, the stadiums look better; weather effects look more prominent too.  The game has various options for how you can view the match; such as bird’s eye view, or touchline settings, personally I went with the director’s view most of the time because it adjusts to the best angel depending on where the ball is.

FM2016, has the new game modes as mentioned above, the regular full FM experience,  and a sort of watered down version, aimed at an audience who don't want to spend hours looking over numbers and statistics, this mode allows people to play matches in a couple of minutes and maybe complete a season in a few hours. If you want to get the full experience out of this game, the Full Game mode is the way to go, if you want a casual experience, maybe try with the classic mode.

As with all other FM games in the series, this game has ample replay ability, and I will easily see myself racking up hundreds of hours in this game. It will suck every second of your spare time and more if you let it. You can finish a season in the regular mode in maybe fifteen hours, that's just one season. You can effectively play this game forever, the game will just keep going and you'll eventually have yourself your own footballing universe which you'll probably find more interesting than the real world.

Even though this game is still in beta, I have had no technical issues with this release thus far. I will keep this review updated in case I do run into any, but as of now, this is a technically sound game and runs like a dream.

To sum up, if you are a fan of Football, and want to learn about the management side of things, or want to drop the FIFA franchise and try something different, you will find no other game out there that does it as well as Football Manager. It is a no brainer for me to recommend this game for any football fan. If you aren't so much of a football supporter, you'll probably want to skip this over, as you may not fully appreciate the content on show, but for me, this is a must play.


Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
I've been a BIG fan of the series from CM right through, owned every release, and hand on heart im honestly disappointed that this years FM was nothing short of a small update on FM15 which in turn you could say was also a small update on FM14, besides the fact they added the feature of create a club and fantasy draft, you could do the first anyway with the editor, they've just made it easier for people.

The game itself is as though the difficulty level has been set to extreme, i have started no less than 8 saves with 8 jobs ranging from League 1 in England to Premiership clubs, all using different tactics, training methods and backroom staff, and the problems are all the same, with every club.

Injuries - Too many and way too long, one club i had 8 first team players out injured, 5 where over 6 months. This not only has an affect on results but other players happiness because results aren't positive, creating a game that you dont want to play. Same thing happened in every club.

Player prices, having to sell cheap and pay over the odds, again. This is nothing new with the game and i was under the impression it was fixed, clearly not.

Goals.. Every other game my teams concede a goal within the first couple of minutes of a match, even when on counter/defensive or attacking etc when starting off
The amount of times ive conceded a goal immediately after scoring is ridiculour. This hasn't just happened a few times, it's continuous, one game ended 4-4, i scored 17, they scored 18th, i scored 23rd they scored 25th, i scored 53rd they also somehow scored 53rd minute, and the last goal was 4 minutes into injury time after i scored on the 89th. I nearly threw my PC out the window.

There are other bugs and parts of the game which aren't up to scratch, so overall dissappointed.

Try the beta first if you an, make your own mind up, this could well be my last year playing FM.

reviewText:
Overall I like FM again. 8/10

Pros
- Addition of Prozone. Huge, Huge addition to the game.
- Realistic Injuries. Injuries still happen but not as frequent and not as drastic.
- Star system isn't as restrictive.
- Improved transfer negotiations.
- Better Contracts

Cons or mild irritants
- Press Conferences. Very much improved but over time could become boring.
- Match Engine. Appears the same but a lot less errors.

Definitely would recommend this game, improvement over FM 2015.

reviewText:
I already said good bye to my family. Hopefully I will find time to stop playing around April for my daughter's first birthday.

EDIT 1.0
On a slighty more serious note. I've been a huge fan of Championship Manager since 1990's, and I bought every iteration of Football Manager.

This year, as always, SI delivers.

Let's be honest - in the past we often received a flawed product, that was playable only after first big patch. This time - I don't see many bugs. Sure - I have a feeling that there might be slightly too many long injuries (my wingmen got injured for 4 and 6 months... then 2 of my attackers got injured for 2 months), but I do also take into account the fact, that I am leading a team with rather poor staff support.

This is the good, old Football Manager. No revolution this year, but as usual it feels like a more complete experience than the previous one.

Long story short: if you love football, and management games - grab it. If you can live without some adjustments that FM16 brings - stay with FM15.

Personally - I am happy that I bought it, and I am playing it like crazy :).

reviewText: I've been a fan of FM for years and years but this version is awful. The simple way to describe it is it's too hard but not in a challenging way, in a totally unrealistic way. The irony this is supposed to be one of the most realistic simulation games you can get. I'm no newbie to FM so am familiar with the tactics and systems but in this game you are instructed by you assistant to change your style constantly through each match. In real life a team has a style of play, they may change it slightly for certain teams or certain periods of matches but no dramatically. In each game I would be told retain possesion
date: play it short" then 5 mins later "hit long balls" it's so random you're not crafting your teams and implementing your style on them
recommended: you're just fluffing through each match hoping you win. I gave it two full seasons before quitting forever.\nI even downloaded other people's tactics to see if I was just rusty. They would be ok for 2 games them I back to the drawing board. In real life teams don't change styles every 5 games to stay fresh
hoursPlayed: they adapt and develop but don't have to redefine.\nNot only is the above with tactics true but there are other infuriating habits - I went ten games conceding in the last ten mins

reviewText:
The match engine must have been designed by Moynes. Every cross is an auto goal. 4 Defenders between the goal and the forward receive a cross or 0, a goalk keeper that 'Rushes out' and one that prefers to say in. A deep sitting team or one pushing forward. A cross will find the forward like a magnet. Whether the winger is crossing it from the middle of the field or by the corner flag. You can watch 5 defenders and a goalie all stupidly stare at a cross while a mediocre forward from a lower league connects with the perfect fit.

But maybe you say I am just a bad FM. And that is possible -- except you can look at the statistics of every other team. 80% of goals are crosses. In fact thats what most matches are between two evenly matched teams, its cross and counter cross.

The other banalities of the game are just quirks of FM -- a sliding tackle strips your player but the ball falls to another one of your player who gives it back to the sliding player -- but the crosses simply take you out of the game. Presumably some programmer watched a game once and saw a cool cross from the deep land perfectly on the tip of a strikers foot and decided that this is the only way goals can be scored.

Oh and also there is a pretty nasty memory leak. But thats usual for FM engines so if you soldiered on through to 2016 its no surprise.

reviewText:
To those who are still on the fence about FM16, dont buy it. Stick with FM15. There isnt much more than cometic upgrades and improvements to talk about. Such as icons where there were none before, and new colors on menues etc.

As far as the ingame match engine goes, it actually seem worse than the FM15 with A L O T of horrible bugs and completly unrealistic things happening. Closing down, marking, passing and keeper work is abysmal. Keepers on Premier level are conceding goals in such a way you most definatley will struggle to keep all of your hair intact after a few hours play.

As mentioned the closing down is also a freakin joke. Top players running passed the ball instead of collecting it, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ man marking or closing down where palyers seems to have opposite magnets attached to them.

I could go on and on and on and on and on about why you should NOT buy this game, but take my word for it. If i could get a refund i would, and i've bought every single game since the first Championship Manager back in the early 90's.

reviewText:
Buy this game if you like being locked in a room all day, vitamin D deficiencies, and just simply don't want to deal with the confinements of real life anymore. Because trust me, once you play this game, there is no going back. The only people interaction you will have in the real world is with the Pizza delivery person.

Pros:
+ New Prozone match analysis is extremely useful especially for those who create their own tactics, and speaking of tactics; the tactics manager is refined and is easier to use than ever. With a completely redesigned set piece creator that makes the difference between building a winning tactic and a losing one much more distinct. It's easier to see where your tactics are going wrong / right, and because of this, if it's going wrong you're going to be able to figure it out much more easier than last year's iteration.
+ Draft Mode is a winner, Who doesn't love fantasy football? Now you can have it inside your favourite football management sim.
+ Injuries aren't as horrifically prominent as they were during the early builds of last year's game.
+ Create-A-Club mode allows you to create your own team and lead your creation to glory. (Replaces a team in the league you choose)
+ Realistic data for almost every player in the WORLD playing across tens of thousands of different leagues. That's just phenomenal!
+ Refined matchday Engine with better 3d graphics.
+ Still easily the best football management simulation in the world, and most likely it forever will be with the sheer amount of work put into this database. This game is a literal universe inside your PC, load it up and you'll be sucked into another dimension where suddenly YOU were actually good at football in the past, and have retired to lead Wigan Athletic to champions league glory.

Meh:
= Press interaction is slightly more varied this year, no more pressing random buttons and hoping you didn't say something to ♥♥♥♥ your star player off. The new conferences will keep you intrigued for at least the first 24 hours of gameplay. (Then it's back to your ol' Assistant Manager because you have nothing to say A la Jose Mourinho)
= Customizing your own manager is neat, but it lacks options. There are only a few different choices for hair styles, colors, and outfits. It doesn't prove to be the immersive feature it is advertised as, because I couldn't copy my likeness.
= The beta is not without it's fair share of bugs, from the silly, to the game crashing; and i'm sure the first versions of the full game are likely to have some too, but it's to be expected with the sheer size of this game. It will just get better over time though, as the devs are highly active and the final version of FM15 was almost bug free from my experience.

Cons:
- Chelsea are actually good in this game.

reviewText:
I think this is the first Football Manager in a few years to offer some actual innovations rather than just 'tinkering' with the system and interface.  It's about time that happened as well as some aspects in the game were getting really quite dated, especially the match engine.

On the subject of the match engine: It really looks like they have tackled this in 2016, especially regarding the goalkeeper and defence, who now actually interact as players on the pitch instead of just going through the motions for the engine.

Tactics ACTUALLY seem to work for once, so asking for direct football will actually get you direct football with forceful wingers and killer balls attempted.  They had started to try and fix this in 2015, but still seemed like they were going through the motions to mask a pretty average match engine.

I am really enjoying the new detailed staff page as well, you can now see exactly who is doing what at the club, and where your club ranks in the league at staff skills.  This was always an underdeveloped part of the game for me, as a club's backroom staff is just as important as the players on the pitch.

I hear the prozone is good as well, but not something I have looked at in detail as of yet.

There are, however, still some issues:

The blighted over developed press conferences are still in the game.  MY GOD these are boring, and I don't think SI actually realise how dull they have made this, which is ironic as a lot of development time seem to have gone into making it 'intuitive'.  Let's make this clear though - intuitive means nothing if it isn't entertaining.  My solution is simple...drop all the press nonsense, that just kills playing time, and allow people to have a preset button which gives you avatar a way of dealing with the press - range it from 'conspiracy theorist' right through to 'upbeat and passive'.  You can then change you demeanor as and when you see fit - so if you are in a slump you can do the 'world is against us' mentality if you wish to, without having to spend 5 mins reading through very dull rhetorical journo questions! The whole 'get your assistant manager to do it' just doesn't wash for me either, as press management is an important part of creating a team mentality.

The interface still looks like it was developed by a sociopath, however I get SI not caring too much as Steklo will no doubt just create a great new indie Skin over the next couple of months anyway.

reviewText: Massive improvements from the disappointments of recent years. Animations are more realistic and the 3d match is now a joy to watch. Nice subtle touches have made the whole experience far more enjoyable.  Everthing just seems more intuitive now and it actually feels like the decisions you make and instructions you give actually make a difference.  Last year's issues with injuries and silly ai seem to have disappeared and we finally have the FM we've been waiting for for the past 4 or 5 years.  It's taken a while to get to this point and there's been a lot of tears and frustrations along the way but, I can honestly say as a long time Champ Man/FM player, I think SI have finally nailed it.  Hurrah!

- get used to draws. Had TWELVE draws in a row in one save.

- its either steamroller opponents or exrcruciating draws. Peppered with an insane ammount of stoppage time goals.

These things never really bothered me before, but they are almost identical complaints stretching back as far as I can remember. It feels jaded to me, and if you're new to the franchise I'd recomend getting 14 to see waht you think. Thirty odd quid for 2016 isnt worth it IMO.

reviewText:
Falling out of love with this long time franchise, that sums up my experience over the last few years,

Reading many online forums and the constant glaring submissions from people like myself -

- Injuries ........... over and over again
- Constantly passing to the opposition, worldclass players turning over the ball like park footballers

- Work the ball in or near the box only to have 3 - 4 oppostion players pack a scrum on my player making impossible to shoot
- Players wont follow game tactics at all, wont pass, wont run into space, wont defend

Its a real shame to watch this franchise unravel like this, 1000's of game owners make the same complaints and yet they still release the game with all these concerns for last few years.
The list goes on and on but I am just over this garbage, take the game back 4 years where players followed instructions and the games were at least a fair contest.

F***ing Joke.

reviewText:
The 88 hours spent on FM 16 were the most frustrating of my life. Let me explain:

First, the 2016 version was the most expensive available on the launch date. But it seems clear is that the efforts and resources have been used to take a coach to the edge of the field and the game interface in general. The game engine has regressed.

Several matches of the best leagues seem to be the lower divisions of European championships. Players do not have any reproach to fail, fail and fail. Not to mention that it's not uncommon to see your team concede almost all the goals in the same way: Crossing.  No matter what you try to do to change . And moreover, in a half season I conceded three goals of crossings that fall straight into the goal. Those unintentional. I was playing in Serie A (Italy).

Finally, the game is heavier than ever. A simple alt + tab to access the internet while the game is simulated is enough to make any video or site becomes very slow.

I could speak a lot about other issues like interface, injuries, lack of more complex choices about tactics or finance, but what really bothered me was the poverty of the game engine.

If in previous versions - some exceptions - you could feel in the skin of a football coach in a top league, in FM 2016 you look like a coach of a farm team speaking a language no one understands.

reviewText:

First of all, the Game makes Fun, it is better than the years before and keeps evolving, everything gets bigger and deeper.

The Match Engine is strange? I think it is the best Engine EVER in any Game. Every Player, Trainer is so different and every aspect can win or loose you the game.

Injuries? First, in the Beta it was really hard, but now its realistic (Watch Arsenal, Chelsea, Bayern...) Every Team can have a injury problem. But with a good medical Stuff, good Rotation, resting Players sometimes, Good Fitnesstraining in the early Season and dont rush injured Players back to quickly you WONT HAVE A JUNURY PROBLEM.

I played 4 Seasons as Dortmund (i still wait for my first Title, Pep keep doing triple´s all over again...)
And first Multiplayer Season with Stoke, its so much fun to play with a Friend, this is best Game for me.

I recommend this game for everyone who loves Football. By FAR the Best Manager.

reviewText:
I'm seriously beginning to wonder why Si put a tactics system into the game at all....it doesn't do anything.

Pressing = follow player to byline and allow cross
Man-Mark = follow your target to the half-way line if necessary
Run with Ball = Stand Still until tackled
Roll ball to defenders = kick ball into area where none of your teammates are present
Shoot on sight = shoot from 90 degree angles
Cross more Often = Pass Backwards
Look for overlap = Pass ball between full back and winger

The list is endless. Every year Si make the game less and less enjoyable and more and more scripted.
Dull

Example: Playing Tottenham away. Conceded four due to RB consistently coming inside to press the CM. RB instructions? Press Much Less/Stay Wider. Can anyone explain WHY player instructions do not work?

It takes Si about 6-7 months to patch the game to make it actually responsive. By that time they are almost ready to release the new" season update. I Will not be buying another Football Manager."

reviewText:
The game is scripted.

In my first test game to experiment with how things have changed since 2013 (when I last purchased a FM), it was clear that results are pre-determined based on variables which it appears are impossible to influence on match day.

As an example, I re-played a single game five times, with three different formations (4-4-2, 4-1-3-2, 5-3-2), and slight tweaks to the two formations that seemed to work the best.

In all five instances, the game was a 2-2 draw, with exactly the same players scoring, within a five minute range.

In other words, no matter what I did in terms of team selection, role selection, formation selection, tactic selection and temperament selection, the game played out in precisely the same manner.

Other games I have re-played in the range of 3-4 times, with exactly the same results as the first play through, and the same scorers (for the opposing team), but at slightly different times.

Personally, I get the feeling that the creators of this game have lost their drive to create a simulation in favour of an easier code which can develop results based on far fewer variables which cannot be changed on match day by the player, most probably to reduce the load on the CPU, but probably to also reduce the amount of work they have to put in.

If anyone has the same feeling I'd be welcome to discuss this issue further.

reviewText: This is, without question or shadow of doubt, the most unacceptable version of this game to date. It has reached a point for me, a most loyal fan of this series, where I begin to question if this is in fact the game itself or some counterfeit. The tactical screen has been butchered and appears as if designed by minds no elder than the age of three years old. The rate at which injuries takes places is an utter disaster and though it is apparently similar to that in reality, within the framework of this game it is a total failure. Then there's the worst part, this business of manager avatars. In the 3.7 billion years that this world has existed, there has never been anything so pathetically panderous to the lowest common denominator. I am not, and have never been a twelve year old girl. And to some extent, that's regrettable because a twelve year old girl would not have spent any of her not earned money on this game. I weep, nay, flood tears of weighted blood from my eyes at the sheer sight of its disastrous layout. It is aggregious, utterly flat in its failing attempts to be appealing. Playing Football Manager has felt this strained and that upsets me dearly. I have never before complained about this game, rather I have tried desperately to have friends or colleagues join me in the trappings of its ever flawed brilliance. But this version just doesn't have the charm. The graphics have never been good, but somehow that never mattered before. I didn't need it to look real; it was, in its way, real to me. The difficulties and stresses that one incurred in their endless search for glory were never so...disconnected from the user. It feels like everything about it that once exhilarated me so has just been swept under the carpet of the fruitless search for realism. This was once the game I sought after most, the game that inspired me most, that excited me most, that drew me most into its world. Now? Now, it's an algorithm. A poor one at that.

reviewText:
Beta review 20 hours played.

Much better, lots of improvements to the UI, the ProZone tactical analysis tools have really transformed the way you can find data about player and team performances, strengths and weaknesses etc, navigating the data is now much simpler and more streamlined without losing any of the insane depth and detail.

Match engine has really recieved some love, more animations, more variety in player actions, the refs now play advantage, keepers behave in a more realistic way, flair players do flairy things, donkeys don't.

Too many little touches and enhancements to list here, every time I play I find something new.

I liked 2015, it wasn't the giant leap forward we were hoping for, however 2016 is, the bar has definitely been raised significantly with this release and the game has moved considerably in the right direction.

So far this is my favourite update in the series, simply because so many areas of the game have been so significantly upgraded, nothing really Earth shattering or game changing, just a lot of much needed polish and it's been made more accessible and intuitive to play.

Well worth the money, this latest iteration of the game will definitely steal far too much of my time.

reviewText:
In my opinion this is the best Football Manager for a while and I have owned all of them to date (not the Championship Manager range)

New bits:
-Create a manager is a bit too gimmicky, not really much of a worthwhile addition
-Set Piece Creator is a massive improvement, allowing much more tactical depth
-Fantasy League is great fun with friends and if you have nay you should definitely give it a go
-Prozone analytics are extremely useful if you can put the time and effort. Usually if you are struggling, you can dig into the reasons why and make adjustments
-Create a club allows you to add a whole new level of personal attachment (although this was never a problem with FM

There are also a myriad of changes. You won't see these if you just pick up the game, of play a couple of matchers. If you are a life-long fan who has played 1000s of hours you will know the AI transfer make more sense, you will know the injuries are more realistic, you will appreciate that the game is harder now and that all round the UI is more usable and friendly.

The same old issues around the press conferences are here, the 3D match engine is a lot better but still not amazing but if you are an FM fan, this is the best iteration for a long time.

reviewText:
Whilst being a long time player of the Football Manager and knowing how infuriating the game can sometimes be, I hate to say that I just can't recommened it. Tactics that you have embedded into your team will NEVER work, players never seem to want to pass the ball, instead just standing in one spot trying to flick and turn against an opposition player, whilst having a man in acres of space who can build to a better attacking position left out in the cold. Players will needlessley head the ball on when they have 10 minutes to bring it down and control it. Your players will make desicions that range from daft to downright bonkers. Goalkeepers who aren't sweeper keepers will charge out to gather the ball whilst ignoring the 8 other opponents that have somehow managed to get inside the box with ease. As your pacey winger is darting downfield, a defender with a pace rating of 7 will manage to overtake and claim the ball. It feels as though everything designed in game is made to benifit the opposition AI as they will always score goals that seem ludicrous, whilst your players constantly shoot wide and high 2 feet from goal.

I watch alot of FM players online and constantly wonder if I am playing the same bloody game, now I'm certainly not the best FM player, but I have certainly felt the highs and lows the games are usually known for, with FM12 being the personal preferance as that game seemed to have a good balance with it's mechanics and AI, you really could go on an amazing run of games only to have a surprise upset on the cards.

I can't say the same magic is felt here though, it is all downhill, from the first game in charge, if you lose, there will be no way to pick yourself up, teams that you should easily beat, will EASILY beat you, and your players will never perform at a level that is ever acceptable.

But it is Football Manager, so of course I'm hooked. I'm sure when I'm 1000 hours into the game I would of finally won a game

reviewText:
I don't like giving negative reviews, but this is very, very similar to FM2012 (I haven't played 13/14/15, so can't comment on them)

Improvements? Well, the layout is a little cleaner, and there's a couple more bells and whistles (coaching badges, Director of Football) but still, it has the same junky match engine, mundane press conferences/team talks, and the tactics/squad screen is still as under/overcomplicated as you want to make it.

Oh, and the manager creator is *ugly*. Seriously, we're talking 25 year old graphic quality here. Back to Amiga level.

If I was reviewing this as FM2013, I'd be hard pressed to recommend this over 2012. The way things stand, I've asked for a refund.

Considering a game from 4 years ago is just as good (and in some ways, even from 90 mins of playing, I found to be better) I can't recommend it.

Oh, and it caused my graphics card to crash on first load, so the first 30 minutes of my 92 I played, were trying to get it to start.

Avoid.

reviewText:
Do NOT and I cannot emphasize this enough. Do NOT buy this game.

Have played FM since 93 and this is by far the biggest regression suffered by any game I can think of.

Utter disaster. Everything about this game is one huge frustration. The match engine is a joke, where all the players seem to have undergone full frontal lobotomies and forgot that they were in fact footballers playing a game of football.

Everything else in it is just drudgery and certainly not anything I would call fun.

While some will suggest improved AI and complexity, I will suggest an utter catastrophe.

Until they fix this game, I am back to FM 15. If anyone wants a FM16 license they can take it off my hands for a six pack or just a kind thought.

Do yourself a favour and skip this version all together. This is Just a much much worse FM15.

reviewText:
After the madness of Football Manager 2015 when every goal you conceded was from a corner or cross which frustrated a lot of players because there was nothing you could do about it since it was a match engine issue (it was sorted out a few months after release in a patch) i welcomed the release of FM16 expecting everything to be fresh and issue free and after 15 hours of playing FM16 i see no issues at all.

One of the main reasons why i love this game is the Create A Club" feature. After doing a load of seasons on a real team i go into the FM editor and create a team Like Jersey FC (Jersey Channel Islands UK football team) which isnt on the game and start in Vanarama Conference South and work my way up the leagues so this new feature was something i was really looking forward to and it works really well.

it just seems that on most occasions theres way too much information being thrown into your face but this isn't really a problem as there are many interfaces created by people on the steam workshop and its pretty easy to find one that suits you best.
The match engine is showing its age slightly now and before you think I'm going to say it should look like FIFA graphics i dont think it should but more importantly there are no issues with it that i can find this year and watching the matches in 2D or 3D is enjoyable once again.

As a fanboy of the FM series and played every FM since 2005 (over 1000 hours on FM12 O_0) I would say this is the best FM since FM12. People are saying that there is not enough improvements or new features to justify the price tag and i do agree but if you buying FM for the first time or been dissapointed with FM14 and FM15 then this is worth a buy"

reviewText:
63 hours in and I think it now time to give my review.

Football Manager 2016 provides more or less the same experience as last year minus the initial bugs, they seem to have taken the last patched version of the match engine from 2015 and used it for 2016, this is not a bad thing, Sports interactive managed to get the match engine working pretty well after a poor release to 2015 - The issues with the match engine on Beta and full game release as we all know where the stupidly high scoring games, and the inability to defend any type of cross by the opposition.

Pros,
Match Engine,
Realistic Injuries
Prozone (although turns a bit gimmicky the more you get into it)
New tactics system.
Layout.
Online games.
More in-depth scouting options,
Impressive Transfer realism and contract negotiations.

Cons,
Make your own manager - The graphics are embarrassingly shocking and the feature is absolutely pointless.
Tactical player icons – Why do you change them every year SI? Why? Stick with the bloody kit icons!
Press conferences – Click. Click, Yawn.

All in all Football Manager 2016 is a slight upgrade on 2015, with some impressive but subtle tweaks but the game is still a must have for any Football Manager fan and definitely won’t disappoint.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since the days of CM, there are very few editions. if any that I haven't bought and played.

It's a shame that I have to say FM 2016 is the worst edition of the game I have ever played. I have put in a lot of hours but it just gets too much when you are watching a match engine that is totally awful.

It seems designed to stop good sides winning too many games by too many goals, so deliberatly will make world class players slam the ball into the post from a tight angle constantly when all he has to do is roll it to the players in the middle. Head the ball inside the 6 yard box? Crossbar or post, guarenteed.

Opposition GK's putting in world class performances, making half a dozen world class saves, on top of all those times you hit the post from 1 yard and he gets a rating of 6.6.

Crosses are totally over powered, get a decent cross in the oppo will score everytime, you do it you will score a heck of a lot, but that's where the world class saves start coming in.

Players go off on international duty? Here, have him back injured for the next 8 weeks!

The only way defenders get good ratings is if they score.

Really, so little effort seems to have gone into this edition it puts me off parting with my £35 for the next one.

TLDR - Match engine is shockingly bad, don't waste your money.

reviewText:
I haven't played this game much, but it's been love at first sight. I played FM 14 and decided to skip FM 15 as I fell in love with my saves. This has been a huge improvement, despite what many say. I believe that the game's stats seem to be reflected on the pitch so much more. No longer are stats numbers on a paper, you see a distinct change in highlights, which wasn't visible previously. Dribbling and flair traits are so much clearer to see, along with pace, strength and more. Animations are a bit off, but FM isn't about graphics, it's about the game itself.

Scouting is so much better. Along with the new in-depth stat pages, coaching and much more. Press conferences can be disabled if you don't like them, but in truth I love them. It makes it feel a bit more real for me and that's just great.

All in all, stop reading this and buy the damn game. It's brilliant

10/10

reviewText:
SI has become complacent due to the lack of competition.

I don't think the developers are upgrading the match engine. They are developing multiple game simultaneously, and 1 year is barely enough time to upgrade database, improve graphics and UI, and make a few adjustments; that's the extent of what they seem to do each year. SI usually spends 3 months patching the game so the development window is probably even shorter than a year.

In other words, you are being horribly ripped off every time you pay for their 'new' product which is more like a patch developed for some months with new graphics and animations. I bet they are using the same engine they've been using for a decade because many core problems never go away in FM series. As a rule of thumbs, you should never buy products released every year.

Returning problems that plague FM every single year are still here because devs refuse to spend time to improve the game.

I took a team predicted to finish at 24th in English 6th football division. In 4 years, I won 4 leagues, promoted the team 4 times, won 8 cups, and the team's wealth was increased 50 folds. Meanwhile, my weekly wage increased from 1000 euro to 1200 euro because the board constantly tries to knock down your wage after each successful season. When I took that team to the premier league my status in the club was 'favourite'; not a legend, not even an icon.

I had two player with the exact same abilities and potential abilities. One had 1 ambition, the other had 20 ambition. The latter doesn't have an agent and the former always requests 3 times more wages and complain about not playing in a bigger club.

Interviews and commentaries are SAME word to word with FM 2006. You are forced to answer mind numbingly boring questions over and over for the same response and news.

Cross is ridiculously OP as it was in earlier versions of 2015. Match stats are wildly different from real soccer. (top players in real soccer marks 90~95% pass success rate. In FM it's 80% at best. Neuer's save rate was 91% in 2015 season. In game it's less than 60%. etc). Goalkeeper AI is horrendous. They often pick up an imaginary ball while the attacker dribbles past him.

To be honest, FM isn't a bad game. It's probably the best sports simulation game available on the market. That doesn't excuse them from cash-milking gamers with the same product every year. If you are a new player interested, sure, go ahead and buy the game. Otherwise, stick to FM you have because new versions don't offer anything new or better. New FM game is microscopically better than its previous installment.

There are a lot more problems but I will just end with this note: FM series has NOT been evolving for almost half a decade. Don't give these people your money. Support developers who actually make a better game than their previous games.

No matter which league you choose, which club you manage, which players you sign or tactics you use its impossible to do well.  I've tried being small teams, average teams, big teams etc. Serious flaws with the game - i've seen my Arsenal team concede 4 goals to a non league side, and the lowest rating of my players was 7 - and that wasnt even for the keeper!  Usually start off well but by mid season, start losing every game by 3 or 4 goals and your team stops scoring - yet players all still get good match ratings and get annoyed when you tell them they were poor.  Some ridiculous player decisions - i've seen Ronaldo clean through on goal then turn around and hoof the ball back to my keeper, which was intercepted by the opposition who then scored - several other bizzare things like that.  I'm glad i got the game when it was half price, and even then i feel ripped off! How can they have made it so bad?

Worst Football Manager thus far. Been playing the games since FM08 and usually log several hundred hours per game. My negative review has zero to do with an inability to win or a bias about a team I support not being good. reviewText:
I decided I will not write a typical Review like in previous years. When I spent some first hours with the new Football Manager 2016 some time ago I discovered a lot of big and small improvements and new features from which I was happy. This article is not a typical review, it’s list of my most favorite new features which can be very helpful for every player.

Interface

The first thing I want to mention is „Side Bar Icon Only“. This feature is very welcome by me because I chose this in every custom skin in last year version. So I’m very glad that IS implented this to the default skin. You can turn it on in Prefferences. There are many new features in your News. I very like the option to view match higlights stright from your mailbox. The higlights of every matches in concrete round, not only your match. Just click on the TV icon and higlights will load and show after a couple of seconds. The Home screen also looks better because there are more panels and you can see the stadium picture next to information about your next match (if you use some of stadium pictures pack of course). Great addition is in Squad Status panel where you can open the list of injured players or wanted players if there are more. That’s fantastic new feature because you don’t need to go to the squad screen a check who is injured.

The Player Profile Screen was revamped as well and I’m big fan of it. There is more information in one screen and if you have a big resolution you can see all the important info about your players.

Staff

Same as the Player Profile Screen was improved the Staff Profile Screen is better in FM16 with bigger amount of information. More important new feature about Staff is there is newly Staff Shortlist with same function as Player Shortlist. You can now add some coaches, managers or other Staff to the shortlist and you can have information about them in one screen. You do not need to search them again every time you need to know something about them.

There is new screen with Staff Overview where you have graphical representation how many Staff you have and you can see Staff comparison with other teams in league you currently play. You can go stright from this screen to other screens like „Coaches Allowed“ or you can arrange meeting with Board and talk about Coach Wages and more. It’s much faster and it saves your time.

Your Staff also can give you a better feedback about your players or tactics and they can recommend you some changes in tactics when you go to Staff Advice meeting.

Tactics

The new Tactics screen was (and will be) very duscussed by all users around the blogs, forums and social media. I was a little surprised when I saw the „squares“ for the first time but the most important thing is if it works well. And after some time with the new look I have no problem with these squares. You can quickly change some information in tactic pitch and the new Suitbaility for role and duty icon and overal physical condition/match sharpness icon is very useful for me.

Other

One of the very important new feature is revamped Set Pieces creator in which you can save up to three routines for corners or free kicks. You can share these routines as tactics. That could be very popular within the FM Community. Another very good feature for me is some information in your mailbox. The information about training camp squad is better same as the news about International call up where you can see which player is missing (and why) or which player was nominated to the national team for the first time.

When you start a new save you can choose when the game will start. You can choose from Early Pre-Season, Start of the Season or First matches of Champions League/Europa League.

There is a new feature about your profile in the game. You can now set up your Avatar which you can see during the match in the dugout. It’s a nice try but this is not much important for me so I don’t want to say if it’s good or bad idea.

I probably forgot something, but I believe I wrote the most important things. I love the small new features in general so I think I will discover some other during next weeks and months. Enjoy FM16.

You can read more on my blog https://mrkeysirensie.wordpress.com/

reviewText:
A direct comparison between this and FM2015 - I'm not sure if it was worth the upgrade considering they literally change less than fifa games

Match engine is clearly looking a lot nicer, with nicer animations. The match engine now looks like FIFA 2008 unlike FM2015 which looked like FIFA 2003 at best. While the animations are now better, it still has the visual issues that FM always had, like the 'inch perfect' tackles always look like fouls, moonwalking into a volley, and the fact that dribbling and technique is invisible and it looks like the defender just doesn't want to tackle. The physics seem to have changed also, the ball floats a bit more and bounces a bit more. Lower league players (conference etc) still literally have autism rather than just being bad players. Players who are prone to injury are still injured for 90% of the time at your club. Aggressive and temperamental players still get sent off every other match. Old players still become literal snails at any point past 30. Apart from that it's a nice visual upgrade, and if anything makes FM2016 worth the upgrade, it's the match engine.

The interface changes are effectively a reskin. It takes a while to get used to, and I guess it's nice, but I wouldn't consider a reskin a selling point. They upgraded the set piece creator too, so now you can create several routines and share them among tactics.

They added some detail to the already annoying interviews so you have to answer a few more questions to avoid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ them off.

They changed around a few words like 'match fitness' is now 'match sharpness'.

That's literally it.

No, it's definitely not worth 35 ♥♥♥♥ing pounds but I bought it on ♥♥♥ so it was only 13 pounds. I don't know if it was even worth that.

But I like football manager as a whole, so if you don't already own an FM game and want to try it out, I suppose you can get this one.

reviewText:
Once again the Football Manager series has succeeded to impress me.  This year Football Manager packs the same experience, but with a lot of small but amazing improvements.  Here are my experiences with this game.

PRO:

- Perfect game for wasting time while work, couch-time (or my personal favourite) college lessons
- Amazingly large database
- Rendering seems a lot more fluid then previous versions
- You don't need an expensive graphics card to enjoy this game
- Winter-update fixed a lot of bugs and made the player ratings more realistic

CON:

- Players have unrealistic salary expectations, allowing small teams to keep big players for way too long
- Preferences seem to reset quite often (maybe a personal issue)
- Limited photo collection of local players and youth
- Sometimes the results are still way to unrealistic.  Allowing me to win the premier league with Liverpool and win the Europa League with a Belgian first division team KRC Genk.  This also packs a lot of inconstency.  Winning with large numbers against big teams, and losing to a 3th division team playing the same 11 and better morale/condition has turned into a habit.

I do in any way advise you to buy this game.  I have been 'wasting' my time on this game, raging and frowning at results, but i couldn't say it felt like i've had the smallest amount of regret buying this game. It's the small things that make a day, like beating a big team or finally grabbing that cup against that small team that tends to play like Bayern Munchen in the cup finals. Overall this game is still amazing.  The positives of the game are definitly worth the small amount of flaws it packs.
Carreer mode is still as addictive as it ever was and challenges got even better.  Online competitions are awesome as you can laugh at your friends as they manage to ♥♥♥♥ up against small teams. If you are in doubt of buying this game, i can assure you, it will be a lot of fun and you just need to buy it. Cheers !

TIP !

Download a logo pack ! Badges and kits can easily be loaded into the game, making the interfaces look a lot better.
