reviewText:
Don't really do reviews, but I wanted to respond to some of the negative reviews.

Generally, I would say this is a significant improvement on FM 2015 (worth asking price? maybe, probably more so than previous incarnations.).  Improvements are mainly to UI and match/performance analysis.

In my experience the match engine has some hiccups (way too many scores from crosses) but I have noticed a significant improvement since launch.

To respond to negative reviews (mostly about match engine):

Will you sometimes get a match where you get 10:1 shots and lose? Yes. Will you get an unlucky season (i.e. too many key injuries) and get sacked? Sometimes. I won't say it's all perfect, but I enjoy some randomness.

I have not experienced consistent injustices in the match engine, but for those who are complaining about it: I hope you tried all sorts of different tactical adjustments and considered things like player consistency/chemistry/tactical fluidity before coming here to review the game.

reviewText:
When I played FM 15 I thought the Sports Interactive team were heading in the right direction with this brilliant franchise. The game was clean, efficient, and while there were a few match engine issues, most importantly, I found the game enjoyable to play.

I thought the features brought into FM 15 would develop into an even better game for FM 16, however, to my dismay, the game was underwhelming to say the least. I've felt while playing this game, the Sports Interactive team have unnecessarily tinkered features that didn't need to be in this years version, and their added features are just not relavent to a football management game and have had no significant impact on the overall game play. Like the new feature of designing the appearance of my manager. Whilst it is a good idea, what is the point? Really. The only difference it has made is now my manager has a really sketchy generated face. Another example is the faces of regens. They were fine the way they were! Don't fix something that isn't broken! What was the point in changing something so petty like that. Surely more focus could be put into other areas of the game like the match engine.

I also have some complaints about the overall interface. On FM 15 the interface was smooth, well designed and was efficient. On FM 16 I have felt the interface is chunky. The new player screens are rubbish; they've tried to fit too much onto one screen, the tactics screen is a disaster, no matter how many times they say it isn't. Whilst there are some good revamps of the interface such as the finances screen, again, the interface was just another feature that didn't need to be adjusted.

Most importantly out of all my complaints is the general happiness I get out of playing this game. I find myself getting more frustrated than not playing this game. The amount of work I have to put in to set up one bloody tactic, or to maintain team morality, or to scout for the best players for my club is just exhausting and it’s not something I should feel when playing a computer game. And what do I get in return? I get indecent results, even when dominating the whole match, poor player performance, and an ungrateful board. My penalty taker who has a 19/20 rating has a conversion rate of under 25% whereas all opposition penalties are converted. My players never follow tactical instructions. Even a draw can deflate my whole team after a good stretch of results and then a winless streak commences but then a win has no effect on the team’s morale. I'm generally left angry and bemused after playing FM 16 which is not what I should be feeling all the time when playing a computer game, which in previous editions, has given me overall happiness.

Sports Interactive really need to wake up and start adding features that are worthwhile for the game. Not create-a-club mode or a fantasy draft mode. I don't play this game always to experience the life of a professional manager, I play this game for enjoyment where I can make my own tactics, sign players and win trophies without the game becoming a chore. If Sports Interactive keep this in mind for their FM 17 edition, this game will be as good as it once was But honestly, if they continue the way they have, I can easily see myself giving up on this franchise altogether.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Every year I um and ah about getting the latest version; this year being the longest I've held out since launch.

And, just like every year, I start playing and again realise they have failed to address the one major flaw in the game; that f***in' match engine!!

The flow of the game is random, the players don't follow instructions, and the movement and actions of the players are completely unnatural. The old 'kick the ball at a team-mate which ricochets 30 yards to an opposition striker' still remains, as does the static defending. The forwards still constantly make the wrong decisions in key areas, ignoring team-mates who have an open goal to try and score from ridiculous angles. I hear defenders of the game argue its a strategy game, and not designed to have life-like matches taking place and I agree. But if the players actions dont reflect the instructions, then having the function is pointless. They might as well remove it. I'd rather have stick men who's actions and decisions are life-like, than superb 3D graphics of something that is frankly, embarrasing to watch.

It isnt unplayable, but the other major disappointment is the lack of new features. It is hardly any different from FM 2015. As such, I wouldn't recommend anyone buys the game and had I played a demo, I'd have saved £35 and just looked for an update patch for FM 2015.

Still early days and it may yet surprise me, but all I see is an extension of the extremely tedious media side of the game, which is just as repetitive as it was in FM 2015 and the available responses too black or white.

To me, its £35 for the emperors new clothes.

reviewText:
I hate to say it, but I think that Fm16 is going to be my last. At least for a while.

I'm no veteran - FM12 was my first FM, and it did not take long to learn the ropes. I applied my skills and knowledge of football and it seemed to work. FM13 was the same. I was more than happy to spend my money buying each new edition. However, that all changed in FM14 - the first truly horrendous game I encountered. The same knowledge and skills I had used no longer worked. FM15 was an improvement, mainly due to the interface. Everything still felt like a roll of the dice.

16 however, is the tip of the iceberg. There is a fine line between entertainment and realism, and to blend both together is tough, but something I think SI achieved in FM12 and 13. But for the past three editions, the balance has been tipped too far towards realism, so much so that FM is now a chore to play.

Whether it be sensitive prima donna players complaining at every opportunity, the AI's deceptive ability to 'adapt' to your tactics after a matter of weeks, match engine errors or the fact that instructions off field are rarely carried out on it, Football Manager is beginning to lose its buzz.

I'm not one to complain just because I'm losing, and there are lots of people who can't get enough of the game. But 16 was a step backwards for this franchise, and after the signs of hope in 15, that is a disappointment. I would not recommend Football Manager 2016 for a newcomer or a regular player of the game. You're better off sticking to 15 or waiting and hoping that 17 is better.

Myself, I am switching to FIFA. At least I know when things go wrong for me in that game, it will be:

a) my own fault, more or less
b) a problem that can be identified and solved. Easily. (Not through three hours of prozone analysis)

reviewText:
Trust me it took deep thought and a lot of second guessing to decide whether I reccomend this game and I think ive decided I dont reccomend it

Positives:
The players move a lot more realistically on the pitch this year. It's a small detail but I think it helps the enjoyment of the match engine.
I would say budgets for teams are fairly realistic so you can run the club making the signings you would expect the team to make in real life, and the odd coup to make everyone happy.
Other teams interest in your transfer listed players is much better this year. Now it is easier to get other teams interested  in buying them although it still isn't a certainty they will be interested. But last year you couldn't shift nobody.
Teams pay a more realistic price for your big name players ie: Man Utd will pay £50 million for Harry Kane rather than £500k and expect it to be accepted.
I feel players respond to your instructions better during the match than last year.

Negatives
Finding tactics that work for top teams on the game is proving to be like a military opertation for me, good luck!
The match engine at times is very scripted making you lose and go on bad runs. ie: you lose matches with shot ratios of 30:1 and possession stats 70%:30% and at times this can just go on and on and on.
When your players are having a bad day, they are having a BAD DAY their attempts to look anything like a legitimate football team are laughable
The same teams always buy the top players (Man Utd).
There is some kind of bug where if you sign a player who you intend to use as a back up on a free transfer the fans become outraged saying it was a ridiculous waste of money when, their free???

Ok, so after more game play time, (about another 2 weeks) it is clear that there is no tactic which the game allows you to use successfully with top teams or lower league teams and I honestly I have exhausted every one, including several wierd tactics through desperation which did nothing. It's not that your team isn't competitive in the match, they 100% are but despite this the game always scripts you to lose. And this isn't me in an upset spat my dummy out tantrum, its very true. I think this is backed up by the lack of successful tactics being posted on forums, there just aren't any. It's a shame that two thirds of the game becomes unplayable because of this. The championship is the only league I have found where a good tactic is actually accepted by the game and it allows you moderate success but it's a huge shame to be so restricted. Ive found I can keep in the top 3 of the Chinese super league with Guangzhou Evergrande. WOW. Some may understand how terrible that is considering their resources and the competition. But Ive tested teams like PSG Barcelona and Tottenham to name examples, and couldn't even defeat amateur teams and therefore as you can imagine I couldnt beat better teams. I was having some success with Watford, until game suddenly decided that without a drop in player performance my tactic would now send me on a twenty match losing streak and therefore the sack. I still had the same shot, possession and corner stats as I did when I was winning by the way. So when the game starts scripting, you just can't fight it.

reviewText:
The theme of this year's installment is definitely one of refinement. The interface is cleaner and more intuitive, yeilding more at-a-glance information than ever before . The player can now spend less time digging through it's various layers to to glean the knowledge needed to improve their team's performance and more time taking action. With a plethora of small but meaningful improvements, the game feels smoother, easier to navigate and less muddied.

The tactics overhaul is perhaps the finest yet and my personal experience suggests that choices made here are more easily realised on the pitch. Set-piece routines are closer to real life than before and multiple routines can be planned and deployed. Feedback on your choices and changes is quick and clear, both on the pitch and from your assistant.
The steady march towards an ever more realistic and immersive experience is resumed in Football Manager 2016. With match engine upgrades, pesky agents, tantrum inducing press, competition overviews that rival the slickest of today's broadcasters and more highlights to watch than the top cable provider package.

The match engine can still look a bit ropey at times, but graphical upgrades along with thousands of new, motion captured, animations, better stadiums and easy(er) on the eye crowds, the progress is really begining to show in this regard.

Contract negotiations are more realistic than ever with seemingly endless ways for agents to embezzle your hard earned cash, but also unrivaled opportunities to tempt that dubious wonderkid to your club.
The inclusion of Prozone match statistics and analysis is incredible and will make a huge difference to how your philosophies and strategies evolve along with many lesser additions like the basic manager/character creation suite, create-a-club and Fantasy Draft modes.

All in all, Football Manager 2016 is a more than worthy entry in this esteemed series. It doesn't re-invent the wheel, but it does come with a whole bunch of new and better ways to use it, all the while in a cleaner, slicker interface.

reviewText: Very detailed game. You literally spend several dozen of hours understanding and enjoying this game. Its not perfect, but its the closest thing on the market that replicates real life soccer. There are a lot of people who are not good at FM, and many of those people don't want to understand how the match engine works, how different positional roles affect each other for your tactics, or how to work the game's transfer market. Those people will not enjoy the game. But if you spend the time understanding this game, then you'll definitely enjoy this game. Go to the FM forum for help when you need it. There are a lot of YouTube videos that offers tutorials and stories how other people manage their teams.

reviewText:
I like how I need 10 chances to score a goal and my opponents need 1-2 shots to score. I will easily draw a match 2-2 where I have 35 shots and they have 3.

I like how the tactics issued arent really followed. I like how the opponent goalkeeper is so much better than my own despite him only having 2 stars and mine has 4.

I like how my defenders act like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and are unable to close down the opponents attackers. Its like I´m playing Barcelona on Nou Camp EVERY match.. And forget about them getting to crosses.. They must have missed heading at practice..

I like how my world class strikers are unable to get their shots on target. He has 18 in finishing but cant hit sh*t.

I like how a 17 year old kid approaches me and demands to play in the first team. I guess he believes he is better than James Rodriguez and Hazard.. Makes sense.

I like how I still have to pay the loyalty bonus to a player who himself asked to be sold..

I like how when I scold my team of superstars after losing 3-0 at home to a team from the relegation zone they feel insulted.

I like how when I have lost three or four matches straight I call a team meeting where I tell them to man up. And they disagree.

I like how Chelsea expect me to pay £120 mill for Hazard and then submit a bid of £30 mill for Pogba.

I especially enjoy how a player that I want to sign expects to get a weekly wage of 250k when at his club he makes 45k.

I simply love when a player expects me to pay him 13.5 mill in loyalty and another 12 mill to his agent..

I like how ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the journalists are and how silly their questions are. Do you plan to loan out XXX XXX?" What the f*ck?? I dont even know who that player is..

I like how my assistant manager tells me to drop a certain player and then two days later when I make him pick the team he picks said player.

I like how I have a £60 mill bid for a player rejected and two days later he is sold to another club for half that amount.

I like the realism when a player tells me "No I will not be joining reigning Champions League champions Milan and a week later signs for West Ham.. Ah the realism..

I like how I could go on forever.. But hey. Its time for PSG to lose 1-2 at home to Bastia...."

reviewText:
Should you buy FM16? Short answer - No, it's a buggy mess!

Long answer...

I just picked up the game yesterday.

Downloaded, installed, started a new game with my favorite Inter and 30 minutes later hit ALT + F4 due to the annoying bugs.

First off, I tried selling a player but for some reason I can no longer just double click on the value to select it all and write what I want. No, I have to fiddle with it! And since Euro values in the drop-down menu are ONCE AGAIN set moronically (11.25m? Seriously?), negotiations are a nightmare for all the wrong reasons.

Next, after we sell players we have to re-invest in the squad. So I send my scouts to get me a report card on a few players for the problem right winger area. And what do they tell  me? They assure me that the right wingers I sent them to scout have potential to be right wingers. Not decent or leading right wingers. Just right wingers. What a revelation!

And finally the straw that broke the camel's back - I send an offer for one of the right wingers with potential to be right wingers, it gets accepted and disappears. None of my staff offer contract, I don't get to do it either and the offer completely vanishes from the transfer center. The cherry on top? When I try to submit the same offer it gets flat out rejected.

What the hell, SI?! It's been months since release! MONTHS! How can ♥♥♥♥ like this still be an issue?!

I'll give the upcoming update a chance but If there's ♥♥♥♥ like this I'll be giving that nifty new refund option a chance instead!

If anyone here is thinking of buying, hold off until the update hits and we know for certain SI have got their act together. You've been warned

reviewText:
Bugs gallore in this version.  I've never had any problems in the past on football manager, but with this one I've had rediculous ammounts of runtime errors, had to reinstall the game several times, and had to put up with task managering my way out of the game and back in, to get it to load up.

Within the game itself, it doesn't seem improved on the previous version, worse if anything.  I'll set my players individual, and strict team tactics to always pass the ball short, i wait months for this new tactic to be fully trained by the team, then i'll watch the match and off they go trying to play lovely long ball.

They say the definition of madness is trying the exact the same thing and expecting different results.  In football manager you can save the game right before a match, play the match, lose, load and repeating, changing absolutely nothing and eventually you'll win 5-0, making you wonder how much impact what you're doing it actually having.

reviewText:
I tried to like this game. I really did.

Unless you are willing to spend hours and hours reading forums about tactics then don't bother.

I started out playing small clubs,  really small ones, so i expected to lose a lot of matches.

but once i got into it a decided to try playing as bigger teams,  I tried celtic,  man utd,  chelsea.  I got sacked from every one of those clubs because we lost every single match,  even if your players are fluid in their tactics, are all star players, are perfect in their positions and have superb morale, brazil will lose to some country that only learned about football a hour ago.

speaking of morale, when holding team meetings, doing team talks, or doing anything in the best interests of your team, will either ♥♥♥♥ everyone off,  or if you are really lucky, only ♥♥♥♥ half of your team off.

someone isnt playing well? individual talk to tell them you have faith in them! but wait! EVERYONE else is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off coz you didnt say you had faith in them...

tell everyone you have faith in them?  wait... now EVERYONE is nervous and stressed coz your putting pressure on them!

I love managment games, and when I first played I really did like this game, but like I said, this game is 90% reading about tactics and 10% swearing at your defence team for standing with the ball at their feet until the other team walk up and take it off you... then your awesome defence will run backwards AWAY from the ball as if it was some voodoo spell that made the ball disappear... then proceed to watch as the other team scores goal after goal

they tried to make the game more realistic by making it difficult,  but the realism is a big team like ManUtd  should be able to beat little unknown teams with a major hangover and their eyes closed,  yet in this game,  even when your team are on full form, they will lose 5-0

I tried to like this game.... I really did

reviewText:
This FM is the worst game I played so far, I remember when FM used to be fun but this one lacks any kind of fun at all. Also the Ai in replays are a lot worse than last years due to the stupid backpasses from defenders for no reason or they get ball and stand still for 10 seconds while the opposition get to the ball, tackle him and then score. The way the replay system works, it would be better without one, nearly every goal seems to be a howler which is either what happens or the replay doesn't depict what happened in the actual game. An example would be my player just scored a goal by sliding it in but on the replay it shows my player standing there and tapping it in.

You get sacked for no reason even if you have good results and the reason I am writing this review now is because I have just had 4 games in 5 days which I can't begin to stress how unrealistic this is or to have no option of contesting it like real life.

Also just to add the new layout is just in your face, like so many bits of information is one one screen now its hard to find what your looking for and there is writing everywhere!! It just looks terrible, it plays a lot worse than previous titles.

By far the worse FM I have played to date, and I started playing 2009.

reviewText:
I benefit from having skipped FM15 it seems.  I can not get enough of this years offering.  The create-a-club was fun for its first year in development.  I hope they dive deeper into this game mode in the future and give us more of a this is all mine!" feeling.

The random regen dates in FM16 help stop the 'Internation Bank of U19' cheese... where you could sign day 0 regens (before AI had the chance to offer them Youth Contracts to their home club) for next to nothing... then develop them for two to three years on minimal salary and sell them for truckloads of cash before having to re-sign them

The control I have over who does what seems greater...  and this lets me use previously untenable attacking options because I trust my own defenders to be where I want them... thus allowing me to be stubborn and score the type of goals I want to see... without leaving me wide open to be countered... I also like that I need more than one way to score... but for me I just change the type of cross/tempo/midfield instructions rather than the actual players.....   FM14 you could play 30 years with only one tactic and have your youth team produce specialists in your system.... I feel like I am punished for not showing the other teams different attacks this year and I am thankful for that

BUT MOSTLY!!!!  This game creates the stink of desperation that English Championship teams must feel to get into the Premier League.... the best players cost vast and ridiculous sums of money... and the good players cost a lot more than servicable squad members.... Hopefully this creates parity in the Premier League... which will make winning virtual silverware feel a bit more satisfying once your 20 years into your game"

Considering how little changes in the game from year to year, I would really expect them to limit their bugs. However, I am shocked to find out, that this year, the promotion system does not even work!

Somehow managed to win the title, and was looking forward to the promotion to the upper league. Never happened. The game kept progressing over the summer break, and eventually a schedule was drawn for my team to play in the same league!

I contacted customer service about this, to which they are only giving me generic replies.

Be warned folks! Stay away from this year's version of this game. Nothing new has been added, except more bugs...

helpfulPercent: and all sorts of other ridiculous minutiae. This is a game where you really can bomb out of first division soccer as one of the best teams in the world. You have to know your ♥♥♥♥.\n\nGameplay: I like the gameplay of Football Manager. Despite the fact that all my friends make fun of me ("Menu Simulator looks really fun but if it doesn't come with a spreadsheet I'm not playing") it's got something that hooks me and will keep me playing for absurdly long stretches all at once. The games themselves are not at the peak of modern graphics but for a game like this to have facescans for every player in the game would be absurd (just wait until you see the number of players in the game). My only complaints in this department are the licensing issues for a lot of teams and divisions. Some of the leagues you'll want to play won't have official logos. reviewText:
It is difficult to recommend a game when it really is an update of an existing formula rather than a new game. I think it is time SI started treating each new iteration as DLC rather than a new title, I do recommend this version, but hesitantly.

That out of the way, is it a good update? Yes. (and no?)

Bad thing first: The new create your own club function is silly and needs TONS of work, you'd think that if they introduce this sort of functionality they'd make sure it was user friendly even as part of DLC. It isn't, all it is is a means to do an editor botch job on an existing club, take their place in the league, change the name, place and colours to your heart's content and finally get really frustrated trying to work out which players you want to add to the club whilst not having anything other than a player-name filter. So that striker you remember plays for Scunthorpe but you don't know his name? Don't imagine you can find him, you can't.

Good things: The U/I has been cleaned up successfully, not just interface wise but also interaction wise, you don't have to do silly repetitive interviews each game any more for example. The game looks clean and fresh, even the 3D engine is now sort of worth using. Another good thing is that the opposing managers/teams now respond to your tactical foibles better, when I added a striker after going 1-0 down the opposing manager didn't wait and switched to a counter-attacking formation straight away, when we equalised anyway he dropped further back but put on a lighting fast striker instead of his targetman. I have never experienced that before in FM20** it used to be more like playing against a scripted bot.

Best thing: The match-engine has had significant work to make it more realistic. I am only a season in so far, but I am very impressed with not just the impact my decisions have on the flow of the game, but also the fact that players seem more creative in their interpretation of my instructions, adapting to the flow of the game if they are more experienced, flapping around the field aimlessly after a mistake if they are youngsters and compounding the problems. Compared to 2015 the tactical side of the game has improved beyond cosmetics, which is what the game should be all about.

reviewText: Please do not delete your FM15 save and buy this like I did. How can a game be such a step down from the last installment? FM15 was fun and addictive and I can't speak highly enough of it, this on the other hand is just pure unadulturated ♥♥♥♥♥. Where to begin? Well for starters how ♥♥♥♥ing hard is it? Every team I play as has the exact same problems and it's like they've cranked up the difficulty 100%. Teams like PSG and Real Madrid that I was dominating as last year are now getting smacked by relegation candidates. I hate using pre-made tactics downloaded off the internet and have never had to in previous installments, but even they don't make a difference! I've iiterally tried twenty different tactics but all of them get undone in the same stupid ways. Instead of creating some trash Manager Creator which makes me physically sick to look at why not make sure the match engine is actually up to scratch? Who was even asking for Create-a-Club!?!? But SI know they can get away with it because of loyal chumps like me. Hoping that the game is patched soon and made better like it was last year or that's 35 quid down the drain.

reviewText:
What you should know about 2016 versus 2015 ?
The best improvements are obviously some new way to show us some statistics with graphics and clever UX.
I always liked to learn a lot of info about players, club, country, records, etc.. And it's a move forward in this 2016 edition.
As always, the in-game rendering was improved, and the generated player too (new faces).
There is a new way to communicate with the stakeholders which make the committee more present and they try to make some improvements in the club, a good point.
The new mods are very good ! Create your own club is a veritable challenge moreover if you want to bring it OTT !
To conclude, all the improvements are smart, no regrets, nevertheless there is only few, don't expect a big change but if you like the fm series you should take it, it's worth.

reviewText:
I've always been a huge fan of the series. I decided to buy the 2016 version after skipping a couple of years and I certainly regret it. It's the worst purchase on steam I ever made.
First of all, the game crashes every single time I play a match for the first time. At some point of the match, the game simply close. Maybe it is related to the version for mac, but I don't have this problem with any other application or game.
The game itself in the management part seems pretty realistic and they added a bounch of good stuff, but the matches are totally buggy and unbalanced. Just to mention the major issues:
1) I get on average 4-5 yellow cards and a red card every match, regardless the instruction that I give to the team for tackling.
2) Unnatural movements of defenders (run away from the opponent with the ball, run in random diractions) lead to totally unrealistic plays. This was actually present in previous editions, and it strikes me they didn't manage to fix it after so many years.
3) When the ball hits a player bounches of several tents of meters in a totally unnatural way.
4) Seems like the ball posession is totally unrelated to the quality of midfielders and their quantity, but is strongly linked to the tatic.. If your opponent plays with the 4 line, he's likely to have the possession, no matter if you have iniesta and xavi in the middle.
5) Also seems, but I may be biased in this, that is far more easy for the opponent to score many goals when he plays better, that for you when you have the edge.
In 10-15 games I either won for 1 goal more or lost by 3-4.
Sure there are some improvements, like more realistic tackling, but these issues make the game really frustrating to play.
Thes issues have nothing to do with ability or tactic, they seem to be totally arbitrary.
Don't buy this game, it's an expensive and frustrating waste of your time.

reviewText: This is the first Football Manager I've played and I can now see why it has contributed to so many divorces. It has a steep learning curve (I recommend starting off by selecting the touch option and  playing a major club until you get all the basics down), however once you get the hang of it, there is no going back. It's on my mind all day, and I'm constantly thinking of tactics and players to utilize. Absolute blast!

reviewText: For some reason I keep buying FM every year and every year I regret it it a little more than earlier years. Some of the interface every year is only tweaked a little compared to the former year but it's not for the better. And every year you can't use your tactics from the former year even though the changes to the tactis interface is only tweaked a little bit. So you have to use a great deal to develop a new tactics again. I just want to play right away and don't want to develop a tactic every year. And FM is not as challenging as it once was once you reach the right tactic. So I'll go back to play one of the former years and stop buying each year.

reviewText:
Ill take this review brief.
I'm a FM player since 2009. But this year SI has made a game with lots of cons and pros compared to previous years' total frustration which adds a bit more positive. Especially as of FM 2014.

Pros
-Transfer System is much better and realistic.
-Interface is more time-saver. Takes a bit to get used to but when you do, its becoming a must-have improvement.
-Match engine -by the looks/graphics only- is improved.
-New manager avatar mode seems a tiny addition and for many people it is useless. But it helps for regen faces to become more realistic if you ask me.

Cons
-ME must be fixed as soon as possible. I'm not saying anything about difficulty. I always back up difficulty and AI reactions. But conceding/scoring the same goals over and over from crosses becomes too boring and frustrating after you play a significant amount of time. Defenders not tackling/closing down as they should. Strikers always fail on one-on-one situations. I hope they will be fixed soon.
-Counter-attacking was always a set-back in previous iterations but in this version they buffed counters out of control. Every player can pass the ball across 40-60m like they are Messi, Beckham or Ronaldinho.
-Player whinings are too contagious within team. They act like 8 year old spoiled girls who their dolls has been taken away.

Whats my result of review?
Buy this game after January transfer window patch is released if you do not want to get angry as the game it is at the moment. More bug and frustration free will it be by then.

reviewText:
I have played each version of Football Manager(or Championship Manager) since it was created on the Amiga and each iteration has improved little by little.

The biggest issue in years gone by has been the tactical aspect. So often, someone managed to figure out a be all tactic that was a plug and play win all trophies. But now with FM16, that is definitely not the case. Now, you truly have to adapt your tactics based upon your players skills and attributes. What works for me at Portsmouth FC may not work for another person as they have bought different players.

The ability of the modding community for Football Manager means that no matter how small the country might be, you can play the leagues for that nation to a certain level. There are people that have made the English Leagues to level 23( the game only ships to level 6) and others doing similar to the Italian or Spanish leagues.

I get great joy in the pure challenging nature of making this game your own with bizarre rules. The number of people that I know are starting game where they cannot buy any players and only use the products from their youth academy. Or can only buy players from a certain nation.

The diversity of this game makes it a great time waster....although....you always need just one more match

reviewText: For seasoned players of the series, FM16 sees some improvements that are fantastic. Better UI, improved match engine, more realistic transfers, more transfers and removed exploits from previous versions. These things generally make the game feel 'better' and more immersive, however the match engine changes and tactics options does make the game feel somewhat unfamiliar. More so than in previous games, this one will take some getting used to again before you can go out and destroy all the competition from the get go. In the end though, a decent step forward for the fans!

reviewText:
I'm writing this on the basis of the BETA version and praying that fixes are implemented in the proper version. I've played every single version of FM (and a couple of CM games) and for me, there's not much new here. Most of the changes are completely artificial and don't improve the gameplay at all. FM15 was the worst and most frustrating version ever, and only time will tell if this is a genuine improvement and will prevent me from ending up in hospital (again) with a self-inflicted fractured skull.

I probably should wait for the proper version to be released before reviewing as the match engine in the BETA version is clearly messed up (I replayed the same fixture 3 times with the same 2 players getting sent off each time, despite making tactical changes) and there are a few glitches which should be fixed by the release date.

I'm recommending this if you're lucky enough to be new to the series as you'll find so many wonderful things to enjoy. Others that have played each version religiously might be more excited about it than I am so far, but first impressions are not promising for me. However that doesn't mean I won't be slumped in a catatonic state in front of my laptop for 13 consecutive hours wondering where my next win will come from.....

reviewText: I am a huge fan of Football manager for almost two decades. I have played over a thousand hours for most of the editions. I just needed to say that this last one feels like the best manager for years now. It has excited me all over again. I havent felt like that for Manager for some years now. Its very rare to feel like that from the beginning of the release. I usually have many complaints till things smooth out. This one is a little gem. Nothing bothers me. Seriously. The match engine is the most realistic till now in my opinion. U really get to see what u do. But what i like most is the immersion. I havent feel this immersive with micromanagement of my team and players since ages. I spend hours checking my players. Their progress etc. Its interface is very intuitive and I cant let it down! Well done guys!

reviewText:
It's good.

They've smoothed out all the weird bugs from the past games (i.e. When you say you want to declare interest in a player and it pauses for 5 seconds), and it's got a far superior graphics system for the match engine compared to fm15. The tactics screen is fugly, but you can now scroll across, so you can fit in even more stats. If you're gonna play it as much as I am, it's completely worth it.

HOWEVER

If this is your first game in the series, I'd go back and play fm15 for a bit. It is much harder this year, and teams get used to your tactics much faster.

reviewText:
Football Manager 2016 is by far the best Football Manager series that has been made under the Sports Interactive series thus far.

Online modes and realism of the match engine has been hugely improved, and a whole lot of frustrating bugs and exploits have been addressed and fixed - much to football lovers satisfaction.
The input of Prozone for match statistics brings huge depth into game analysis.

There is also a cool fantasy drafting/transfer as well as challenge modes added to this year's game.

Overall 5/5 and will keep any football crazy fan engaged for hundreds of hours.

reviewText:
Ok Football Manager 2016. Now I got this on Beta release date and there was a few bugs here and there but thats expected because of the beta.

When the full game released it was not much diffreant from the actual beta. You could use your saves from the beta on the full game which was good and a nice touch by SI. This meant I was able to destroy teams with MUFC further.

Tactics are not as easy as previous years with a open mind I look on the workshop for advice and not many people could give advice. I found that tactics only work for about 6 games and then fail. Although since the winter update I have found my Control OP tactic works a treat with my Portsmouth save.

Transfer were not improved as I would of liked. Overpriced players are still riddled within the game and more frustrating then ever. Something SI need to address for FM17.

The game is quite stable on my laptop which is quite terrible in terms of specs. On my main rig it runs at 5 stars with 8 leagues loaded no problem.

As for touch I haven't as yet tried it as I dare to.

Pros:
- Match Engine
- Quick and Swift Gameplay
- Easy saving options
- Not as bland in terms of Menus as Previous years.
- In general a really nice game.

Cons:
- frustrating transfers
- Tactics are not consistant
- To many Manager sackings
- There are more but the list is to big.

Summery:

In general FM16 is a worth it game with more detail than ever and you will find yourselves playing it at 5am on many nights.

reviewText:
I read lots of negative reviews of this and 15 about lack of progress, things not fixed etc. But actually, jumping to 16 from 10 it's a massive improvement in all aspects I've seen so far (only couple months into career yet). Looks better in matches, less ridiculous player choices on screen, seems overall more detail and some nice slick improvements on UI, despite needing to get used to changes. And I got to make my own team up in my own town, and start them at bottom of available pyramid :)
Is it perfect? NO, of course not. (stupid fragile injury prone players)
Is it good? Yes.

Perhaps not worth the full 5/7, but well worth the upgrade on sale prices if not got a recent FM version.

reviewText: Sort this mess of a game series out SI - you are playing with too many peoples' lives!  If you are going to do that, at least make it enjoyable and give the user some respite when coming to terms with the number of hours they have wasted in front of your creation.\n\nI'm all for a challenge but the novelty and megalomaniacal thrill of becoming a virtual football manager has been painfully lost since FM12.  Too many times have I had the urge to start a new game, play a few months and experience the same, annoying tendencies of the match engine that absolutely drain any pleasure from a gaming premise which should be the most immersive on Earth (at least for me).  I won't go into these peoblems as they are well documented in the largely negative user reviews on Steam.  I consider myself to be an analytical individual - someone who enjoys micro-managing and customizing my gaming experiences to my hearts content.  FM allows you to do this but it doesn't allow you to reap any of the rewards for doing so.  Daylight robbery.

reviewText:
-BETA REVIEW-

8/10

So for so good, things are going smoothly for me, no real issues to report, Haven't experienced the injury crisis or poor keeping (YET). So on my side seems like an improvement from FM15 for sure! Now with a bit more depth, the interface is very likable once you get used to it. It may look a bit messy at the start, but in fact once you've adapted, you realise how useful the new function and layout really is. Players do quite well according to their stats, though sometimes i am a bit frustrated by random upsets, but i guess it mimics real life right?

Anyway, the game is a good platform so for, BETA has been good, no big issues on my part. Maybe keepers should be a little touch better, but nothing really alarming so far. The players also could be a little more decisive as i notice they are a bit slow to react to situations, but i guess its a game, again not a big issue.

To me, the most critical issue with the game, would be the crazy transfer fees requested by clubs for their players (8/10 of my bids were asking for a fee way above the real life price that they would be sold for). So this one i would like to be fixed. Maybe a bit more reasonable valuation of players as well. Cause for example I in no way can see that Falcao is still worth 35Million Pounds.

Overall, good game, look forward to the full release in 2 weeks.

reviewText:
The latest in the ultimate football management series follows the proven blueprint of previous instalments with a few tweaks and improvements to the formula.

Transfers are much more realistic this time around, with negotiations feeling much more authentic and fluid.  Press conferences, while still repetitive and a little too frequent, have also been improved.

The graphics and match engine have been improved and make match day feel more like a real fixture, though we aren't talking about photo-realistic visuals as yet (that'll be Football Manager 2032, probably).

Each advancement has helped to make Football Manager 2016 even more enjoyable to play and the one more click" mentality is sure to extend more than a few nights by several hours at a time.

Win
recommended: you know one thing will alway's be true: it's your tactics.  Apparently."

reviewText:
I've been a regular buyer of FM series and i think this is one of the best ever imho. The changes in graphic, depth in stats (PROZONE), set pieces creator all looks cool. Although it is a beta version, it feels like the original game. Most of the silly bugs have been tweaked accd. to me the AI plays more sharply. The new camera angles, weather,  change in UI is an additional bonus.

If you're expectiong any major updates to this game from FM15, then you're bound to be dissappointed but for me all the small tweaks and additions here and there provides me with an ultimate expericence of football management.  If you're an avid football lover : YOU CAN'T AFFORD TO MISS THIS. For occasional players of FM series : my only advice is to play FM15 with a database update from LFC MARSHALL, SteveWhizzkids etc.

On that note, i'll take leave and go on with my FM adventure surely which would be full of up and downs.
C'mon peeps say bye to your social life.  500 hrs of FM16 here i come!

reviewText:
This is a review of Football Manager 2016, version 16.2.

I've (proudly? not so proudly...?) logged hundreds of hours on FM games over the years.

They have their hit or miss moments every year. The match engine is never perfect, or takes several patches to get to an enjoyable state. Year after year, features are lack luster, or it feels like the devs are holding back good ideas for future years. After buying FM year after year, I decided to hold off on new FM's until there was some real ground breaking stuff, and milk FM 2014 for every penny I could. I played the 2015 demo, and deemed it unworthy. I played the 2016 demo at first, and also found it lacking.

But after reading forums and posts by respected FM community members, I got the sense that 2016 was in a really good place as of the last patch. Many reviews i've read said that FM 16 was the most enjoyable the franchise has been in recent years... so when it finally went on sale 25% off, I decided to bite.

And I've never enjoyed FM as much as I have in the last 30+ hours of playing. The 16.2 match engine feels great... the graphics are respectable... and the UI (after downloading my favorite FLUT skin) is beautiful. I definitely think skipping 2015 was the right move, because 2016 feels packed with features that 2014 didn't have. Like it's almost a completely different game.

If you're a veteran of FM games, and are on the fence about buying 2016. I say do it, especially if it's on sale...

If you're new to the franchise, this is probably one of the most accessible versions of the game to get in to. To get the full FM experience, I would strongly reccomend doing some research on graphics add-ons (like facepacks, logos, UI improvements, kits (jerserys), and other 3D enhancements) from fan/3rd party sites. After spending the day updating all of my graphics and images... FM 2016 is far and away my favorite iteration of the game.


tl;dr:

Buy 2016 (on sale), skip 2017 (unless it's revolutionary). Make sure to heavily customize the graphics. Profit.

reviewText: So I got the new FM16, and i think really good. Better graphics, better organised, quicker to get to the nitty gritty. Generally excellent. Issues? Some really stupid goals,especially in the top levels. Matchday graphics really good but can also be really stupid. Players running past the ball, not controlling and at times looking like a pub team rather than The Premiership Elite. A few updates and tweeks though for the next upgrade and the potential is there. It really looks like a game of football. I will say I dont like the transfer search but that maybe due to not being use too it. In general a vast improvement and with the development of the online side of things really exciting. No life again until at least February. Oh boy. Enjoy :)

reviewText:
I've been playing this franchise since championship managaer 3. After really bad reviews of FM 2015 I decided to skip this one so I have comparision to FM2014.

Pros vs FM14:
1. I really do think that game engine and your players AI was significantly increased. After playing about 20 matches I can tell for sure that watching them is far more interesting.
2. In FM14 you couldn't tell the difference between well skilled player and semi pro player from Southern Football League Premier Division. Ale the goals were scored  pretty much the same way. In FM16 you can really see the difference between technical and non-technical player. Variety of plays and ways goals are being scored.
3. In FM14 defenders AI was absolutely terrible. I know that players from lower leagues can be bad but come one. Many times my GK or defenders were just standing there an looking at a loose ball and do nothing. Just nothing. In my opninion in FM16 there is less amount of stupid and annoing defensive mistakes - it seems more realistic.
4. Way better animations. Players seem to have much more skills.

Cons vs FM14:
1. Just a terrible, sickening, huge amout of yellow cards. When I step up  an aggressive tackling I ended up wiht a red card  in almost every single game. This must be some kind of glitch because it's just impossible.
UPDATE: I've changed tackling to normal and I still get a red card (2 times yellow) in every third, fourth match.


Afterall as a huge fan of whole series I'm really satisfied. FM16 really is an improvement to FM14.

reviewText:
So... after reading reviews from awesome to horrible it was on sale and I descided to try it... (being new to the franchice)

Many frustrating hours, many attemps many restarts this game is not very newbie friendly...

So I decided to pick a 2nd League German team, expectation top half finish... won 3 games then unhappyness started to breed, soon after I got fired...

Did this with a couple of restarts, one time I forgot to include one player in the midseason training camp, the end.

So I finaly managed to surive a season, barely avoided relegation though, made a couple of additions to the squad, started getting rediculessly good bids for my players, job offers and so on, the game was fun, I was doing good, sold the wrong guy... Unhappyness... fired...

This game is extremly unforgiving, one wrong click and your out... wanted to praise a player for his conduct, by accident hit praise game, desaster... Usualy the results aren't completly without merrit but to seem a bit harsh...
The game engine is however a bit funky same players making the right clicks I finished 2nd in the Cup (!) and made the promotion playoffs... and won(!)

In my opinion that is a bit too much range in the power of morale and happyness having done the scenario twice with the same set of plays once losing every game untill I got fired the other time winning allmost everything and beating the crap out of champions league teams...

In order to try to fix unhappyness I once tried to arange a friendly against a very small reputation team... 39-2 shots, 17-1 on target 0-1 the result..

The game is challenging, and as long as you pay attention to what you do its fun, but the happyness morale factor weighs too heavy in both directions...

now to chose one of these thumbs thingies...

Yes I recommend the game, it may be tough, but not completly random and unreasonable. When you have time and patience to work your way through its very deep and rewarding and gives you lots of stuff to do.

No I do not recommend the game to newbies, except if you have a lot of nerve and are willing to restart several times because the game is so very punishing. And also spend some time reading guides... you're lost without.

reviewText:
Very Good - 9/10

what is good -

the menu - the menu is well designed and is easy to find your way through it, if you dont like the style you could easily download a better skin

coaching - definately one of the best aspects getting a good coaching team is fairly easy - again download shortlists for this - however buying in an entirely new backroom staff may be a bad idea as they take time to get used to the players and can be bad when sorting out that starting line up

tactics - important to change them up as teams in the league will adapt and find ways to counter your style of play TIP - if you are on a bad run definately shake the team around - easy to function more visual in many ways and again easy to understand

youth squads - extremely fun to develop youth stars in to first team players, gives off a sense of accomplishment however buyIng in youth players is usually very expensive and may make you reconsider

the workshop - i say this because it is fun and interesting to get players such as pele into the squad and have a lot of fun making these amazing squads with players of the past

finances - very in depth pretty obvious dont spend too much as it can easily criple the club and watch out for FFP especially if you are a smaller club, can be confusing at the start however after a short look fairly easy to understand

scouting - simple and effective tells you who is good and tells you who is bad not much else to say

what is bad -

3D match engine - looks very tacky at times and even abnormal players passes or shots look too unrealistic could be a lot better however their are upgrades in textures online

what is okay -

in-game editor - fun to use to change names or that however can lead to you changing one too many things with the power definately a great tool however shouldnt be that pricey, their is however a function to disable it recommend unless you are not going for a serious game!

overall FM16 is a fun game with a lot of replayablity takes a fair amount of time to get in to the game itself if you are new, definately gives you a fairly accurate insight into the footballing world, big warning though can be extremely frustrating when things dont go your way,

Enjoy!

reviewText:
9/10

I've been playing since 2008 and once again FM has improved the game from it's already high standards.
Prozone is an awesome addition to the game allowing you to see stats from all the leagues you have enabled for your database.
Changing of tactics feels like it has more of an influence on the game now, such as changing of mentalities (attacking, control, counter etc)

Still stupidly addicitive too, I find myself sneaking an hour in during work time or going to bed 2 hours later than planned due to 'one more game...'

The only reason it doesn't get a 10 is the frequencey of injuries (something I'm putting down to beta mode at the moment). At one point my Man united team had 9 starting 11 injuries the shortest of which was 7 weeks.

reviewText:
After many years of enjoying the Football Manager franchise this years copy doesn't dissapoint. From more of a first immpressions point of view having tried the fantasy draft as well as the new features in customising how your manager looks is a really nice touch and adds more dimensions to an already quite complex and thoughtful game. Menus are still great this year apart from a few tabs which hold some really handy imformation such as information on the league, players etc. which I found myself having to go through a few different tabs, overall being quite hard to find.

From a gameplay point of view, apart from a few goalkeeping mistakes which have been quite frustrating to deal with, the game continues to allow you to create your own identity, to find a system within the players you have which can lead you to success. If you want to play a Sam Allaydyce route one system, Barcelona Tiki-Taka or the Pochettino press, all is avaible to you and takes times and tinkering to find the right plan for you.

Overall, I am again pleased with this years game and look forward to playing it into the future.

reviewText: I have played FM for some years now and I must say I'm loving this one so far. I think the gameplay is harder than previous games but that makes it a lot more fun. There's no more unbeaten seasons where your lead striker scores 3 goals every game. You actually need to adapt to the team you're playing against. Players feel more real and the menus and charts are gorgeous. It won't feel that much different from FM 2015 but it is and why change if 2015 was almost perfect?! No true FM fan will need this review but I'm leaving it for those who are hesitant to go for it. I did have some minor graphic issues that I quickly solved by going to Sports Interactive's forum. There's an error that the producers didn't change wich is the lack of study I'm doing and my future in shambles. But hey I was coach of the year!

reviewText:
I bought it early just because I'd grown a bit tired of FM15 due to knowing 16 will be out and I'll move over to that, this allowed me to play the BETA, which I enjoyed until the matches began. Marking, ... infact, defending seemed to be a thing of the past. I play as Arsenal as I support them so find great longevity in managing them. However, no one marks, no one makes tackles or tracks anyone. I beat a 2.5* Australian team 6-5... Back and forth, it was hideous.

RC1 came out and the first game seemed better, made more sense, but then I lost 5-1 away to southampton, from a lot of goals where defenders were almost running away or tackling the ball to an uncoming striker for him to score 1 on 1.

Now the full game is out this has been less noticable and I haven't lost a game down to a bad match engine since, just diego costa running rampant. Anyway, as always with a new FM, there are kinks to straighten out, but I believe the transfers are so much more realistic and I love how i can keep on Wenger as a director of football. All in all, great game, interface will take getting used to, but same thing happened when I went from 14 to 15 etc... play the demo, give it a go, I'm sure over the next few months patches will be introduced which fixes bugs.

reviewText: I had 1,000 hours in Fm15. As soon as I got FM15 I got right into the game. Yet, with FM16, I struggled to get a save I liked. It wasn't that the game was bad, or that I got relegated. reviewText:
Ok I'm going to keep this simple and brief.

The biggest question I'm am going to answer first is what is the main difference between 2015 and 2016 for all the hardcore football fans. For me the biggest difference is that know it now shows you which attributes are important for which coaching abilites. I'm sure a lot of you had to google them and probably save a copy on your desktop to look at from time to time, I know I did. The biggest issue I have had with this game until now was finding good staff members which usually takes me an hour or two at the start of every game. Now with this small added feature it takes me at most 30 minutes which I don't mind at all.

Now with that out of the way, for newcomers this game is addicting as hell. If you are into football and management style then this is an incredible game. Manage your favourite team and take them to new heights. That's the mentallity I have whenever I play this game. Be prepared though, it's not easy. It is realistic enough to excite you as well as fustrate you. You DON'T get to play the matches. Don't compare this to FIFA or PES. This is purely a management game so the graphics aren't exactly top priority. There are so many different indepth options that you will spend ages learning them. Again I recommend this for football fans. If you are not into football then this game could get boring very fast. You have to micro-manage every single player and staff member if you want to have the best team in the world. I am currently in my 3rd season with Roma. The first two season went well with 2nd place finishes in Seria A and a Domestic Trophy. This season everything is going to ♥♥♥♥ and I don't know why but I can't stop playing. I feel like Jose Mourinho. If you don't know who he is then don't buy this game.

100/10 Would do everything again

reviewText:
Just as addictive and fun as previous years, a bit more polished this time around. FM still ranks as one of my favorite games year after year. The match engine is solid and the AI seem better at adjusting to your tactics, so you can't just Mourinho your way through a season with the same tactic and players every game.

My one gripe with the game is the press conferences are still a bit bland and could probably use an overhaul. It doesn't really detract from the gameplay that much, though.

Overall, very challenging and very rewarding. I highly recommend for any fan of the sport and/or anyone who enjoys statistics and analytics. This game is heavy in both.

Just buy it already.

reviewText:
This is the best foot manager so far, they are getting better. AWESOME!!!

Well, I recommend that you ALWAYS START UNEMPLOYED. Because to be honest its to easy to start with Real Madrid, Arsenal or any big club with lots of money and already big name players. But seriously where is the fun in that??? Plus you will play 3 or 4 seasons then proberly get the sack because you will have one bad season and not meeting the boards expectations. Then you will quit and start a new game. Pointless in my view.

STARTING UNEMPLOYED is the way. Yes you will end up getting a rubblish club with no money, crap players and more than likely limited staff.

I started off with Lowestoft, no money, no scouts and crap players, but I had fun trying sign some decent players that i couldnt scout. And I did, though I started unemployed, I never got a job till mid October so the season was well on its way and Lowestoft were rock bottom in the Vanarama North. I signed a couple of good players and still I struggled to get them out the religation zone. In fact I got the sack with 6 games to go (a bit harsh I thought as I was only 2 points from safety) but hey ho, thats football management for you.

Anyway back unemployed searching and applying for jobs I managed to get a job with Chester right at the end of the season and they had been religated already to the Vanarama North.

So that was my first season, not great but i found it a joy to play. Fantastic!!

Being that Chester were religated my bonus was that I had some decent players already. Tom Peers and John Rooney are proberly the best in the team. And I had a much better season as I did win the league and I never sold any players and only bought in 2 players. I'm now in my second season with Chester (my third incl Lowestoft) and had released and sold a few players and got a few more decent ones in and still loving it and doing well.

So starting unemployed is so much harder, so much more interesting than starting with the big clubs.

If start at the top - the only way is down.
If you start at the bottom - the only way is up.

11/10

reviewText:
9/10

I've been playing since 2008 and once again FM has improved the game from it's already high standards.
Prozone is an awesome addition to the game allowing you to see stats from all the leagues you have enabled for your database.
Changing of tactics feels like it has more of an influence on the game now, such as changing of mentalities (attacking, control, counter etc)

Still stupidly addicitive too, I find myself sneaking an hour in during work time or going to bed 2 hours later than planned due to 'one more game...'

The only reason it doesn't get a 10 is the frequencey of injuries (something I'm putting down to beta mode at the moment). At one point my Man united team had 9 starting 11 injuries the shortest of which was 7 weeks.

reviewText:
Football manager is a true joy for everyone who loves football.
The visual upgrades make everything much more overlooked and obvious.
The overview screen catches every important standing and statistic in little windows with quicklinks to go the more detailed view.

The new tactics screen is also more consumer friendly. For example if you change a player it now marks the ones fit for that  position in green.
The team instruction windows is now devided into 4: System, defence, buildup and attack. This makes it much more clear as to how your tactical choices will influence the game.

The most fun part about all football managers however is experimenting with your own dreams about football:
- Make Jesus Navas your royal right back.
- Gets 10 MoM and 23 assist and sell him to Barcelona.
- Realise you made a mistake by selling him.
- Buy a 19year old attacking left midfield  wonderkid with the money and turn him into your new royal attacking right back.

Amazing game.

The only thing that currently needs improving (in my opinion) is the first team players complaining about lack of playing time too much.
I know your own stats can make it less likely for them to complain, but in my opinion their complaining is usually based on nothing. And you can't really give them that as a possible answer. If you have 3 games/week. and you only play them in 2/3, They will still complain.
Also the injuries is an every year discussion. I had 8 first team players (Touré, Silva, Aguero, Otamendi) on long term injuries at once. That was probably a bit too much of bad luck. But they will probably patch that later like every year.

reviewText: Having not played the franchise for a fair few years, i was quite excited to get back to the heady days of FM and see how it had changed.\nThe sheer quantity of stuff you need to think about is positively mind-boggling. this probably explains my ability to get teams up a division, and then stagnate. Had to resign from Cambridge, having got them promoted to League One, before I got sacked. Got the Middlesbrough job next (how, I hear you cry?!) and got them promoted. lasted a year in the Premier League, then resigned in November of year 2 after a humiliating 5-1 defeat to Newcastle. in hindsight, I wished I hadn't. I'm now conquering all before me (domestically) as Dinamo in Croatia. Getting thoroughly embarrassed int he CL group stages, mind.\nIs it realistic? Yes, insofar as it frustrates the hell out of me, like football in real life. Can my strikers score? Not very often. Do I want to throw things? Yes. Will I keep playing? You can bet your life on it. I just hope my wife isn't reading this over my shoulder.

reviewText:
This is going to be quite an in-depth review and i will be adressing pretty much every aspect of the game that i can think of. As you can see from my play time, i have been absolutely addicted to Football Manager 2016 since buying it just after New Year, and i cant see myself stop playing anytime soon.

Gameplay:
The actual game is absolutely fantastic. FM16 was actually my first Football Manager game, and i can tell you now it wont be my last. The intstructions in-match actually make a difference to the game, which was a nice suprise for a long time FIFA player. I would recommend this to you if you are confident in your tactical skills in football, it will be a nice test for any football fan.

Saving:
My issues with game saves were fixed in the recent update. I now have no problems and am loving this game even more.

Realism:
Compared to FIFA Career Mode (which i have been playing for the past 6 years or so) the realism is on another level. In career mode, it is easy to sign top players or any player for that matter, but in FM it gives you much more control in transfers, and the budgets are similar to what i would give to each club, based on their financial state.


Thanks for reading guys, definetely buy this game

reviewText:
This is the best foot manager so far, they are getting better. AWESOME!!!

Well, I recommend that you ALWAYS START UNEMPLOYED. Because to be honest its to easy to start with Real Madrid, Arsenal or any big club with lots of money and already big name players. But seriously where is the fun in that??? Plus you will play 3 or 4 seasons then proberly get the sack because you will have one bad season and not meeting the boards expectations. Then you will quit and start a new game. Pointless in my view.

STARTING UNEMPLOYED is the way. Yes you will end up getting a rubblish club with no money, crap players and more than likely limited staff.

I started off with Lowestoft, no money, no scouts and crap players, but I had fun trying sign some decent players that i couldnt scout. And I did, though I started unemployed, I never got a job till mid October so the season was well on its way and Lowestoft were rock bottom in the Vanarama North. I signed a couple of good players and still I struggled to get them out the religation zone. In fact I got the sack with 6 games to go (a bit harsh I thought as I was only 2 points from safety) but hey ho, thats football management for you.

Anyway back unemployed searching and applying for jobs I managed to get a job with Chester right at the end of the season and they had been religated already to the Vanarama North.

So that was my first season, not great but i found it a joy to play. Fantastic!!

Being that Chester were religated my bonus was that I had some decent players already. Tom Peers and John Rooney are proberly the best in the team. And I had a much better season as I did win the league and I never sold any players and only bought in 2 players. I'm now in my second season with Chester (my third incl Lowestoft) and had released and sold a few players and got a few more decent ones in and still loving it and doing well.

So starting unemployed is so much harder, so much more interesting than starting with the big clubs.

If start at the top - the only way is down.
If you start at the bottom - the only way is up.

11/10

reviewText:
Having not played a FM since FM 14 I was interested to see the changes that have happened in 2 installments of the series. I was impressed by the excellent UI that is fairly (not completely but fairly) intuitive. Secondly, the incredible polish of most of the new features such as Create-A-Club, which is astonishingly well made and complex and Fantasy Draft, an excellent multiplayer idea that is great fun. It also has seen a nice improvement in the match engine as the animations are better, there are more animations and generally the highlights feel a bit less scripted and unpredictable.

On the other hand, there are some blinding flaws with the game. First of all, the fact that defenders are just a bit inconsistent is a problem that needs patching as soon as possible. At times they can block shots brilliantly and defend almost perfectly but at other times I have seen one cb boot the ball off another cb into the net for a truly spectacular own goal. This happens whether it is Bayern Munich or FC United so making so that buying a new cb for £30 million is actually worth it. In addition, the new manager creator is a really poor feature that needs sorting out in the next installment. It is very limited and the manager you create ends up looking like a playdough model of a manager with a potato instead of a head.

Overall, I would say that if you love FM and just want the new FM buy it now but if you played FM15 and didn't really like it then I would consider waiting till next year for a more polished game.

Rating: 7.75/10

reviewText: Really enjoying this game, havent played since fm13 however it is very simmilar, one thing that stood out for me was the exact same dialogue options when you have your first chat with the clubs chairman, and pretty much the same pep talk although it seems they have a lot more of an impact then fm13. other then that its the same quality game, but a little better, more interacions from other managers and players and its enjoyably realistic. for all the reviews saying its no good and they lose all the time i can only suggest searching up about how to play the game (and i dont mean that in an offensive way), read tips from the experst who spend their whole lives playing this series :p but a few tips i found were- watch your games in at least comprehensive, and use 2D pitch,  much better for analysing how your team is playing. dont have just one tactic, and never underestimate the effect good scouts, coaches and assistant coaches have on your team aswell as other factors like training, morale and chemistry. the in game help seems overwhelming but there is so much even a fairly experienced fm player can learn. the other thing i seemed to read about was injuries and i will agree they do seem abit unrealistic.

reviewText:
I was a bit late to the Championship Manager party, with my first CM game being 03/04, the last one to be properly made by Sports Interactive. However I've been on the Football Manager gravy train since that first iteration in 2004 and have been playing them to death ever since.

Football Manager 2015 is the first time I was genuinley disappointed in the series, although my hours had waned on FM in accordance with a rise in work commitments I was still managing to plug away and get plenty of hours in. FM 2015 for some reason never grabbed me, no matter who I played as or what I tried I always seemed to have issues, be it transfers, tactics, injuries. Not to mention that I found the new look interface to be awkward.

As a result I was extremely dubious about picking up 2016, for the first time in years I didn't buy an FM game at launch and after looking at many of the early reviews on Steam I felt my decision was justified. January rolled round and I decided to give in, surely it couldn't be that bad...?

Turns out it isn't, in fact it's the best FM game in a few years, I'm absolutely addicted once again. A real return to form!

reviewText:
*DISCLAIMER*
I'm a newbie to Football Manager, FM15 was my first go around.(I'm an American and only recently fell in love with the sport)

I was a bit worried to grab this game, after it's initial release all the reviews were very very bad. I fell in love with 15 very quickly and wanted to get 16 as soon as it came out. But in came all the bad reviews and I was hesitant.

A few months later I picked it up on a steam sale, And I haven't regretted it one bit. The addition of staff shortlists is very nice. And contrary to many reviews THEY FIXED INJURYS YAY! This was my biggest issue with 15, and they sure fixed it. I've only have 2-3 seasons over my whole time playing that I was plagued with injury. Which is realistic, some times teams have those kinds of season, but never four players injured in a single match/etc.

I can't tell you how it compares to past FM games, but as a newbie to the series I quite enjoy it. It's slightly improved from 15, so if you're on a budget, just buy 15, or wait for it to go on sale.

reviewText:
Football Manager. One of the rare series that would see you spend a few hundred hours at least on each edition regardless of how rubbish the game is.

This year's edition is decent. The match engine works quite well now I have to say.

Transfers are STILL too expensive, though understandable considering how the transfer market has changed since my first ever FM (2011)

The UI is a lot better than 15's. A lot more refined and with more stats you care about.

My only gripe? Leicester got relegated in 2017 in my save, therefore very unrealistic right now.

All jokes aside, if you never played an FM game before you might want to pick this one up (Or wait until 17 comes out and be inevitably unplayable until next March). If you already played FM 2015 and haven't picked this up, I reckon you should wait until there are major changes because this game really feels like FM 2015 came out of open beta. It also has to be noted that you cannot transfer your savegames from 15 to 16.

Recommended only if you want a better version of 15.

(And has anyone tried to win the league with Leicester after recent events? I know I did. I failed.)

reviewText: unfairness to the extreme. played with Valencia and I have built a very strong team which won the la liga for 2 consecutive times. every time when my team played against Barca we were favourites to win, but no matter what style we play Barca will dominate the game and create extremely high number of attacks. There is no such thing as defence in the game as they can simply beat you even I have already built a team that is the strongest in the league. That may be realistic in real world football, but the game is supposed to let players do something that they cannot do in the real world! Such bias to a team is truly disgusting.\nanother thing is that whenever a player's team goes behind, time passes very quickly without any meaningful events happening, you will just see players fouling your team and getting lectured instead of booked. You won't have the chance to even launch one attack. But when an opposition team is behind, they got all the time in the world to attack. They can get up to ten attacks in just 45 minutes. Players who watch only commentary should know that it is rare to see commentary of attacks appear for more than 10 times in one half. When they took back the lead the game quickly ends. This game is made very unfair on purpose in order to raise its difficulty". FM really got worse and worse... Do not play this game unless you are a masochist loving to see your hardwork get undone by stupid unfair formulas."

reviewText:
I'm very dissapointed by this game. While it added many new features and better 3D animation, the game simulation is very bad. In almost every game I've played, I dominate the game but I'm unable to score most of the times. That's right, although my team has 10+ shots on goal, the opponent's goalkeeper blocks the shot every frickin' time while the opponent only needs 2-3 shots to score at most. It's downright awful to see players with 15+ Finishing Rating unable to get it past the keeper. Also the injuries bug is annoying as well, the injury toll keeps building up.

This is the first FM game with this issue, I don't know what has changed in the sim engine but it's pretty bad.

UPDATE
I've now received my refund even though I've played more than 2 hours. Thanks for the good support!
